1.1: In the beginning God created heaven and earth.
1.2: The earth was formless and empty, and darkness covered the deep water. The Spirit of God was hovering over the water.
1.3: Then God said, "Let there be light!" So there was light.
1.4: God saw the light was good. So God separated the light from the darkness.
1.5: God named the light [day], and the darkness he named [night]. There was evening, then morning-the first day.
1.6: Then God said, "Let there be a horizon in the middle of the water in order to separate the water."
1.7: So God made the horizon and separated the water above and below the horizon. And so it was.
1.8: God named [what was above] the horizon [sky]. There was evening, then morning-a second day.
1.9: Then God said, "Let the water under the sky come together in one area, and let the dry land appear." And so it was.
1.10: God named the dry land [earth]. The water which came together he named [sea]. God saw that it was good.
1.11: Then God said, "Let the earth produce vegetation: plants bearing seeds, each according to its own type, and fruit trees bearing fruit with seeds, each according to its own type." And so it was.
1.12: The earth produced vegetation: plants bearing seeds, each according to its own type, and trees bearing fruit with seeds, each according to its own type. God saw that they were good.
1.13: There was evening, then morning-a third day.
1.14: Then God said, "Let there be lights in the sky to separate the day from the night. They will be signs and will mark religious festivals, days, and years.
1.15: They will be lights in the sky to shine on the earth." And so it was.
1.16: God made the two bright lights: the larger light to rule the day and the smaller light to rule the night. He also made the stars.
1.17: God put them in the sky to give light to the earth,
1.18: to dominate the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good.
1.19: There was evening, then morning-a fourth day.
1.20: Then God said, "Let the water swarm with swimming creatures, and let birds fly through the sky over the earth."
1.21: So God created the large sea creatures, every type of creature that swims around in the water and every type of flying bird. God saw that they were good.
1.22: God blessed them and said, "Be fertile, increase in number, fill the sea, and let there be many birds on the earth."
1.23: There was evening, then morning-a fifth day.
1.24: Then God said, "Let the earth produce every type of living creature: every type of domestic animal, crawling animal, and wild animal." And so it was.
1.25: God made every type of wild animal, every type of domestic animal, and every type of creature that crawls on the ground. God saw that they were good.
1.26: Then God said, "Let us make humans in our image, in our likeness. Let them rule the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, the domestic animals all over the earth, and all the animals that crawl on the earth."
1.27: So God created humans in his image. In the image of God he created them. He created them male and female.
1.28: God blessed them and said, "Be fertile, increase in number, fill the earth, and be its master. Rule the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, and all the animals that crawl on the earth."
1.29: God said, "I have given you every plant with seeds on the face of the earth and every tree that has fruit with seeds. This will be your food.
1.30: I have given all green plants as food to every land animal, every bird in the sky, and every animal that crawls on the earth-every living, breathing animal." And so it was.
1.31: And God saw everything that he had made and that it was very good. There was evening, then morning-the sixth day.

2.1: Heaven and earth and everything in them were finished.
2.2: By the seventh day God had finished the work he had been doing. On the seventh day he stopped the work he had been doing.
2.3: Then God blessed the seventh day and set it apart as holy, because on that day he stopped all his work of creation.
2.4: This is the account of heaven and earth when they were created, at the time when the LORD God made earth and heaven.
2.5: Wild bushes and plants were not on the earth yet because the LORD God hadn't sent rain on the earth. Also, there was no one to farm the land.
2.6: Instead, underground water would come up from the earth and water the entire surface of the ground.
2.7: Then the LORD God formed the man from the dust of the earth and blew the breath of life into his nostrils. The man became a living being.
2.8: The LORD God planted a garden in Eden, in the east. That's where he put the man whom he had formed.
2.9: The LORD God made all the trees grow out of the ground. These trees were nice to look at, and their fruit was good to eat. The tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil grew in the middle of the garden.
2.10: A river flowed from Eden to water the garden. Outside the garden it divided into four rivers.
2.11: The name of the first river is Pishon. This is the one that winds throughout Havilah, where there is gold.
2.12: (The gold of that land is pure. Bdellium and onyx are also [found] there.)
2.13: The name of the second river is Gihon. This is the one that winds throughout Sudan.
2.14: The name of the third river is Tigris. This is the one that flows east of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
2.15: Then the LORD God took the man and put him in the Garden of Eden to farm the land and to take care of it.
2.16: The LORD God commanded the man. He said, "You are free to eat from any tree in the garden.
2.17: But you must never eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil because when you eat from it, you will certainly die."
2.18: Then the LORD God said, "It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper who is right for him."
2.19: The LORD God had formed all the wild animals and all the birds out of the ground. Then he brought them to the man to see what he would call them. Whatever the man called each creature became its name.
2.20: So the man named all the domestic animals, all the birds, and all the wild animals. But the man found no helper who was right for him.
2.21: So the LORD God caused him to fall into a deep sleep. While the man was sleeping, the LORD God took out one of the man's ribs and closed up the flesh at that place.
2.22: Then the LORD God formed a woman from the rib that he had taken from the man. He brought her to the man.
2.23: The man said, "This is now bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh. She will be named [woman] because she was taken from man."
2.24: That is why a man will leave his father and mother and will be united with his wife, and they will become one flesh.
2.25: The man and his wife were both naked, but they weren't ashamed of it.

3.1: The snake was more clever than all the wild animals the LORD God had made. He asked the woman, "Did God really say, 'You must never eat the fruit of any tree in the garden'?"
3.2: The woman answered the snake, "We're allowed to eat the fruit from any tree in the garden
3.3: except the tree in the middle of the garden. God said, 'You must never eat it or touch it. If you do, you will die!'"
3.4: "You certainly won't die!" the snake told the woman.
3.5: God knows that when you eat it your eyes will be opened. You'll be like God, knowing good and evil."
3.6: The woman saw that the tree had fruit that was good to eat, nice to look at, and desirable for making someone wise. So she took some of the fruit and ate it. She also gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it.
3.7: Then their eyes were opened, and they both realized that they were naked. They sewed fig leaves together and made clothes for themselves.
3.8: In the cool of the evening, the man and his wife heard the LORD God walking around in the garden. So they hid from the LORD God among the trees in the garden.
3.9: The LORD God called to the man and asked him, "Where are you?"
3.10: He answered, "I heard you in the garden. I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid."
3.11: God asked, "Who told you that you were naked? Did you eat fruit from the tree I commanded you not to eat from?"
3.12: The man answered, "That woman, the one you gave me, gave me some fruit from the tree, and I ate it."
3.13: Then the LORD God asked the woman, "What have you done?" "The snake deceived me, and I ate," the woman answered.
3.14: So the LORD God said to the snake, "Because you have done this, You are cursed more than all the wild or domestic animals. You will crawl on your belly. You will be the lowest of animals as long as you live.
3.15: I will make you and the woman hostile toward each other. I will make your descendants and her descendant hostile toward each other. He will crush your head, and you will bruise his heel."
3.16: He said to the woman, "I will increase your pain and your labor when you give birth to children. Yet, you will long for your husband, and he will rule you."
3.17: Then he said to the man, "You listened to your wife and ate fruit from the tree, although I commanded you, 'You must never eat its fruit.' The ground is cursed because of you. Through hard work you will eat [food that comes] from it every day of your life.
3.18: The ground will grow thorns and thistles for you, and you will eat wild plants.
3.19: By the sweat of your brow, you will produce food to eat until you return to the ground, because you were taken from it. You are dust, and you will return to dust."
3.20: Adam named his wife Eve [Life] because she became the mother of every living person.
3.21: The LORD God made clothes from animal skins for the man and his wife and dressed them.
3.22: Then the LORD God said, "The man has become like one of us, since he knows good and evil. He must not reach out and take the fruit from the tree of life and eat. Then he would live forever."
3.23: So the LORD God sent the man out of the Garden of Eden to farm the ground from which the man had been formed.
3.24: After he sent the man out, God placed angels and a flaming sword that turned in all directions east of the Garden of Eden. He placed them there to guard the way to the tree of life.

4.1: Adam made love to his wife Eve. She became pregnant and gave birth to Cain. She said, "I have gotten the man that the LORD promised."
4.2: Then she gave birth to another child, Abel, Cain's brother. Abel was a shepherd, and Cain was a farmer.
4.3: Later Cain brought some crops from the land as an offering to the LORD.
4.4: Abel also brought some choice parts of the firstborn animals from his flock. The LORD approved of Abel and his offering,
4.5: but he didn't approve of Cain and his offering. So Cain became very angry and was disappointed.
4.6: Then the LORD asked Cain, "Why are you angry, and why do you look disappointed?
4.7: If you do well, won't you be accepted? But if you don't do well, sin is lying outside your door ready to attack. It wants to control you, but you must master it."
4.8: Cain talked to his brother Abel. Later, when they were in the fields, Cain attacked his brother Abel and killed him.
4.9: The LORD asked Cain, "Where is your brother Abel?" "I don't know," he answered. "Am I supposed to take care of my brother?"
4.10: The LORD asked, "What have you done? Your brother's blood is crying out to me from the ground.
4.11: So now you are cursed from the ground, which has received the blood of your brother whom you killed.
4.12: When you farm the ground, it will no longer yield its best for you. You will be a fugitive, a wanderer on the earth."
4.13: But Cain said to the LORD, "My punishment is more than I can stand!
4.14: You have forced me off this land today. I have to hide from you and become a fugitive, a wanderer on the earth. Now anyone who finds me will kill me!"
4.15: So the LORD said to him, "Not so! Anyone who kills Cain will suffer vengeance seven times over." The LORD gave Cain a sign so that anyone meeting him would not kill him.
4.16: Then Cain left the LORD's presence and lived in Nod [The Land of Wandering], east of Eden.
4.17: Cain made love to his wife. She became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Cain was building a city, and he named it Enoch after his son.
4.18: To Enoch was born Irad. Irad was the father of Mehujael. Mehujael was the father of Methushael. And Methushael was the father of Lamech.
4.19: Lamech married two women, one named Adah and the other Zillah.
4.20: Adah gave birth to Jabal. He was the first person to live in tents and have livestock.
4.21: His brother's name was Jubal. He was the first person to play the harp and the flute.
4.22: Zillah also had a son, Tubalcain, who made bronze and iron tools. Tubalcain's sister was Naamah.
4.23: Lamech said to his wives, "Adah and Zillah, listen to me! Wives of Lamech, hear what I say! I killed a man for bruising me, a young man for wounding me.
4.24: If Cain is avenged 7 times, then Lamech, 77 times."
4.25: Adam made love to his wife again. She gave birth to a son and named him Seth, because [she said,] "God has given me another child in place of Abel, since Cain killed him."
4.26: A son was also born to Seth, and he named him Enosh. At that time people began to worship the LORD.

5.1: This is the written account of Adam and his descendants. When God created humans, he made them in the likeness of God.
5.2: He created them male and female. He blessed them and called them humans when he created them.
5.3: When Adam was 130 years old, he became the father [of a son] in his own likeness, in his own image. He named him Seth.
5.4: After Adam became the father of Seth, he lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.5: Adam lived a total of 930 years; then he died.
5.6: When Seth was 105 years old, he became the father of Enosh.
5.7: After he became the father of Enosh, Seth lived 807 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.8: Seth lived a total of 912 years; then he died.
5.9: When Enosh was 90 years old, he became the father of Kenan.
5.10: After he became the father of Kenan, Enosh lived 815 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.11: Enosh lived a total of 905 years; then he died.
5.12: When Kenan was 70 years old, he became the father of Mahalalel.
5.13: After he became the father of Mahalalel, Kenan lived 840 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.14: Kenan lived a total of 910 years; then he died.
5.15: When Mahalalel was 65 years old, he became the father of Jared.
5.16: After he became the father of Jared, Mahalalel lived 830 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.17: Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years; then he died.
5.18: When Jared was 162 years old, he became the father of Enoch.
5.19: After he became the father of Enoch, Jared lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.20: Jared lived a total of 962 years; then he died.
5.21: When Enoch was 65 years old, he became the father of Methuselah.
5.22: After he became the father of Methuselah, Enoch walked with God for 300 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.23: Enoch lived a total of 365 years.
5.24: Enoch walked with God; then he was gone because God took him.
5.25: When Methuselah was 187 years old, he became the father of Lamech.
5.26: After he became the father of Lamech, Methuselah lived 782 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.27: Methuselah lived a total of 969 years; then he died.
5.28: When Lamech was 182 years old, he became the father of a son.
5.29: He named him Noah [Relief], and said, "This child will bring us relief from the work and painful labor of our hands since the LORD has cursed the ground."
5.30: After Lamech became the father of Noah, he lived 595 years and had other sons and daughters.
5.31: Lamech lived a total of 777 years; then he died.
5.32: When Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

6.1: The number of people increased all over the earth, and daughters were born to them.
6.2: The sons of God saw that the daughters of other humans were beautiful. So they married any woman they chose.
6.3: Then the LORD said, "My Spirit will not struggle with humans forever, because they are flesh and blood. They will live 120 years."
6.4: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days, as well as later, when the sons of God slept with the daughters of other humans and had children by them. These children were famous long ago.
6.5: The LORD saw how evil humans had become on the earth. All day long their deepest thoughts were nothing but evil.
6.6: The LORD was sorry that he had made humans on the earth, and he was heartbroken.
6.7: So he said, "I will wipe off the face of the earth these humans that I created. I will wipe out not only humans, but also domestic animals, crawling animals, and birds. I'm sorry that I made them."
6.8: But the LORD was pleased with Noah.
6.9: This is the account of Noah and his descendants. Noah had God's approval and was a man of integrity among the people of his time. He walked with God.
6.10: He had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
6.11: The world was corrupt in God's sight and full of violence.
6.12: God saw the world and how corrupt it was because all people on earth lived evil lives.
6.13: God said to Noah, "I have decided to put an end to all people because the earth is full of their violence. Now I'm going to destroy them along with the earth.
6.14: Make yourself a ship of cypress wood. Make rooms in the ship and coat it inside and out with tar.
6.15: This is how you should build it: the ship is to be 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
6.16: Make a roof for the ship, and leave an 18-inch-high opening at the top. Put a door in the side of the ship. Build the ship with lower, middle, and upper decks.
6.17: I'm about to send a flood on the earth to destroy all people under the sky-every living, breathing human. Everything on earth will die.
6.18: "But I will make my promise to you. You, your sons, your wife, and your sons' wives will go into the ship.
6.19: Bring two of every living creature into the ship in order to keep them alive with you. They must be male and female.
6.20: Two of every type of bird, every type of domestic animal, and every type of creature that crawls on the ground will come to you to be kept alive.
6.21: Take every kind of food that can be eaten and store it. It will be food for you and the animals."
6.22: Noah did this. He did everything that God had commanded him.

7.1: The LORD said to Noah, "Go into the ship with your whole family because I have seen that you alone are righteous among the people of today.
7.2: Take with you seven pairs of every kind of clean animal (a male and a female of each) and one pair of every kind of unclean animal (a male and a female).
7.3: Also, take seven pairs of every kind of bird (a male and a female of each) to preserve animal life all over the earth after the flood.
7.4: In seven days I will send rain to the earth for 40 days and 40 nights. I will wipe off the face of the earth every living creature that I have made."
7.5: So Noah did everything that the LORD commanded him.
7.6: Noah was 600 years old when the flood came to the earth.
7.7: Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives went into the ship to escape the floodwaters.
7.8: Clean and unclean animals, birds, and creatures that crawl on the ground
7.9: came to Noah to go into the ship in pairs (a male and female of each) as God had commanded Noah.
7.10: Seven days later the flood came on the earth.
7.11: On the seventeenth day of the second month of the six hundredth year of Noah's life, all the deep springs burst open. The sky opened,
7.12: and rain came pouring down on the earth for 40 days and 40 nights.
7.13: On that same day Noah and his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, as well as Noah's wife and his three daughters-in-law went into the ship.
7.14: They had with them every type of wild animal, every type of domestic animal, every type of creature that crawls on the earth, and every type of bird (every creature with wings).
7.15: A pair of every living, breathing animal came to Noah to go into the ship.
7.16: A male and a female of every animal went in as God had commanded Noah. Then the LORD closed the door behind them.
7.17: The flood continued for 40 days on the earth. The water increased and lifted the ship so that it rose high above the ground.
7.18: As the water rose and became very deep, the ship floated on top of the water.
7.19: The water rose very high above the earth. It covered all the high mountains everywhere under the sky.
7.20: It rose 23 feet above the mountaintops.
7.21: Every creature that crawls on the earth died, including birds, domestic and wild animals, and everything that swarms over the earth, along with every human.
7.22: Everything on dry land (every living, breathing creature) died.
7.23: Every living creature on the face of the earth was wiped out. Humans, domestic animals, crawling creatures, and birds were wiped off the earth. Only Noah and those with him in the ship were left.
7.24: The floodwaters were on the earth for 150 days.

8.1: God remembered Noah and all the wild and domestic animals with him in the ship. So God made a wind blow over the earth, and the water started to go down.
8.2: The deep springs and the sky had been shut, and the rain had stopped pouring.
8.3: The water began to recede from the land. At the end of 150 days the water had decreased.
8.4: On the seventeenth day of the seventh month, the ship came to rest in the mountains of Ararat.
8.5: The water kept decreasing until the tenth month. On the first day of the tenth month, the tops of the mountains appeared.
8.6: After 40 more days Noah opened the window he had made in the ship
8.7: and sent out a raven. It kept flying back and forth until the water on the land had dried up.
8.8: Next, he sent out a dove to see if the water was gone from the surface of the ground.
8.9: The dove couldn't find a place to land because the water was still all over the earth. So it came back to Noah in the ship. He reached out and brought the dove back into the ship.
8.10: He waited seven more days and again sent the dove out of the ship.
8.11: The dove came to him in the evening, and in its beak was a freshly plucked olive leaf. Then Noah knew that the water was gone from the earth.
8.12: He waited seven more days and sent out the dove again, but it never came back to him.
8.13: By the first day of the first month of Noah's six hundred and first year, the water on the land had dried up. Noah opened the top of the ship, looked out, and saw the surface of the ground.
8.14: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month the land was dry.
8.16: "Come out of the ship with your wife, your sons, and your sons' wives.
8.17: Bring out every animal that's with you: birds, domestic animals, and every creature that crawls on the earth. Be fertile, increase in number, and spread over the earth."
8.18: So Noah came out with his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives.
8.19: Every animal, crawling creature, and bird-everything that moves on the earth-came out of the ship, one kind after another.
8.20: Noah built an altar to the LORD. On it he made a burnt offering of each type of clean animal and clean bird.
8.21: The LORD smelled the soothing aroma. He said to himself, "I will never again curse the ground because of humans, even though from birth their hearts are set on nothing but evil. I will never again kill every living creature as I have just done.
8.22: As long as the earth exists, planting and harvesting, cold and heat, summer and winter, day and night will never stop."

9.1: God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, "Be fertile, increase in number, and fill the earth.
9.2: All the wild animals and all the birds will fear you and be terrified of you. Every creature that crawls on the ground and all the fish in the sea have been put under your control.
9.3: Everything that lives and moves will be your food. I gave you green plants as food; I now give you everything else.
9.4: "But you are not to eat meat with blood in it. (Blood is life.)
9.5: In addition, I will demand your blood for your life. I will demand it from any animal or from any person. I will demand the life of any person [who kills] another person.
9.6: Whoever sheds human blood, by humans his blood will be shed, because in the image of God, God made humans.
9.7: Be fertile, and increase in number. Spread over the earth, and increase."
9.8: God also said to Noah and his sons,
9.9: "I am going to make my promise to you, your descendants,
9.10: and every living being that is with you-birds, domestic animals, and all the wild animals, all those that came out of the ship-every living thing on earth.
9.11: I am making my promise to you. Never again will all life be killed by floodwaters. Never again will there be a flood that destroys the earth."
9.12: God said, "This is the sign of the promise I am giving to you and every living being that is with you for generations to come.
9.13: I will put my rainbow in the clouds to be a sign of my promise to the earth.
9.14: Whenever I form clouds over the earth, a rainbow will appear in the clouds.
9.15: Then I will remember my promise to you and every living animal. Never again will water become a flood to destroy all life.
9.16: Whenever the rainbow appears in the clouds, I will see it and remember my everlasting promise to every living animal on earth."
9.17: So God said to Noah, "This is the sign of the promise I am making to all life on earth."
9.18: Noah's sons, who came out of the ship, were Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
9.19: These were Noah's three sons. From them the whole earth was populated. Ham was the father of Canaan.
9.20: Noah, a farmer, was the first person to plant a vineyard.
9.21: He drank some wine, got drunk, and lay naked inside his tent.
9.22: Ham, father of Canaan, saw his father naked. So he went outside and told his two brothers.
9.23: Shem and Japheth took a blanket and laid it over their shoulders. Then they walked in backwards and covered their father's naked body. They turned their faces away so that they didn't see their father naked.
9.24: When Noah sobered up, he found out what his youngest son had done to him.
9.25: So he said, "Canaan is cursed! He will be the lowest slave to his brothers.
9.26: Praise the LORD, the God of Shem! Canaan will be his slave.
9.27: May God expand the territory of Japheth. May he live in the tents of Shem. Canaan will be his slave."
9.28: Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
9.29: Noah lived a total of 950 years; then he died.

10.1: This is the account of Noah's sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and their descendants. Shem, Ham and Japheth had children after the flood.
10.2: Japheth's descendants were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
10.3: Gomer's descendants were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
10.4: Javan's descendants were the people from Elishah, Tarshish, Cyprus, and Rhodes.
10.5: From these descendants the people of the coastlands spread into their own countries. Each nation had its own language and families.
10.6: Ham's descendants were Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
10.7: Cush's descendants were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. Raamah's descendants were Sheba and Dedan.
10.8: Cush was the father of Nimrod, the first mighty warrior on the earth.
10.9: He was a mighty hunter whom the LORD blessed. That's why people used to say, "[He's] like Nimrod, a mighty hunter whom the LORD blessed."
10.10: The first [cities] in his kingdom were Babylon, Erech, Accad, and Calneh in Shinar [Babylonia].
10.11: He went from that land to Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth Ir, Calah,
10.12: and Resen, the great city between Nineveh and Calah.
10.13: Egypt was the ancestor of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
10.14: Pathrusites, Casluhites (from whom the Philistines came), and the Caphtorites.
10.15: Canaan was the father of Sidon his firstborn, then Heth,
10.16: also the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
10.17: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
10.18: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites. Later the Canaanite families scattered.
10.19: The border of the Canaanites extended from Sidon toward Gerar as far as Gaza and then toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim as far as Lasha.
10.20: These were Ham's descendants by families and languages within their countries and nations.
10.21: Shem, Japheth's older brother, also had children. [Shem was] the ancestor of all the sons of Eber.
10.22: Shem's descendants were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
10.23: Aram's descendants were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
10.24: Arpachshad was the father of Shelah, and Shelah was the father of Eber.
10.25: Two sons were born to Eber. The name of the one was Peleg [Division], because in his day the earth was divided. His brother's name was Joktan.
10.26: Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
10.29: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. These were Joktan's sons.
10.30: The region where they lived extended from Mesha toward Sephar in the eastern mountains.
10.31: These were Shem's descendants by families and languages within their countries according to their nations.
10.32: These were the families of Noah's sons listed by their genealogies, nation by nation. From these [descendants] the nations spread over the earth after the flood.

11.1: The whole world had one language with a common vocabulary.
11.2: As people moved toward the east, they found a plain in Shinar [Babylonia] and settled there.
11.3: They said to one another, "Let's make bricks and bake them thoroughly." They used bricks as stones and tar as mortar.
11.4: Then they said, "Let's build a city for ourselves and a tower with its top in the sky. Let's make a name for ourselves so that we won't become scattered all over the face of the earth."
11.5: The LORD came down to see the city and the tower that the descendants of Adam were building.
11.6: The LORD said, "They are one people with one language. This is only the beginning of what they will do! Now nothing they plan to do will be too difficult for them.
11.7: Let us go down there and mix up their language so that they won't understand each other."
11.8: So the LORD scattered them all over the face of the earth, and they stopped building the city.
11.9: This is why it was named Babel, because there the LORD turned the language of the whole earth into babble. From that place the LORD scattered them all over the face of the earth.
11.10: This is the account of Shem and his descendants. Two years after the flood when Shem was 100 years old, he became the father of Arpachshad.
11.11: After he became the father of Arpachshad, Shem lived 500 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.12: Arpachshad was 35 years old when he became the father of Shelah.
11.13: After he became the father of Shelah, Arpachshad lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.14: Shelah was 30 years old when he became the father of Eber.
11.15: After he became the father of Eber, Shelah lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.16: Eber was 34 years old when he became the father of Peleg.
11.17: After he became the father of Peleg, Eber lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.18: Peleg was 30 years old when he became the father of Reu.
11.19: After he became the father of Reu, Peleg lived 209 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.20: Reu was 32 years old when he became the father of Serug.
11.21: After he became the father of Serug, Reu lived 207 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.22: Serug was 30 years old when he became the father of Nahor.
11.23: After he became the father of Nahor, Serug lived 200 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.24: Nahor was 29 years old when he became the father of Terah.
11.25: After he became the father of Terah, Nahor lived 119 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.26: Terah was 70 years old when he became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
11.27: This is the account of Terah and his descendants. Terah was the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran. Haran was the father of Lot.
11.28: While his father Terah was still alive, Haran died in Ur of the Chaldeans, his native land.
11.29: Both Abram and Nahor married. The name of Abram's wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor's wife was Milcah, daughter of Haran. (Haran was the father of Milcah and Iscah.)
11.30: Sarai was not able to have children.
11.31: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (son of Haran), and his daughter-in-law Sarai, wife of his son Abram. They set out together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to Canaan. When they came as far as Haran, they stayed there.
11.32: Terah lived 205 years and died in Haran.

12.1: The LORD said to Abram, "Leave your land, your relatives, and your father's home. Go to the land that I will show you.
12.2: I will make you a great nation, I will bless you. I will make your name great, and you will be a blessing.
12.3: I will bless those who bless you, and whoever curses you, I will curse. Through you every family on earth will be blessed."
12.4: So Abram left, as the LORD had told him, and Lot went with him. Abram was 75 years old when he left Haran.
12.5: Abram set out for Canaan. He took along his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, and all the possessions they had accumulated and the servants they had acquired in Haran.
12.6: They arrived in Canaan, and Abram traveled through the land to the oak tree belonging to Moreh at Shechem. At that time the Canaanites were in the land.
12.7: Then the LORD appeared to Abram and said, "I'm going to give this land to your descendants." So he built an altar there to the LORD, who had appeared to him.
12.8: He moved on to the hills east of Bethel, and he put up his tent-with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. He also built an altar to the LORD there and worshiped the LORD.
12.9: Abram kept moving toward the Negev.
12.10: There was a famine in the land. Abram went to Egypt to stay awhile because the famine was severe.
12.11: When he was about to enter Egypt, Abram said to his wife Sarai, "I know that you're a beautiful woman.
12.12: When the Egyptians see you, they'll say, 'This is his wife!' Then they'll kill me but let you live.
12.13: Please say that you're my sister. Then everything will be alright for me, and because of you I will live."
12.14: When Abram arrived in Egypt, the Egyptians saw how very beautiful his wife was.
12.15: When Pharaoh's officials saw her, they raved about her to Pharaoh, so Sarai was taken to Pharaoh's palace.
12.16: Everything went well for Abram because of her, and he was given sheep, cattle, donkeys, male and female slaves, and camels.
12.17: However, the LORD struck Pharaoh and his household with terrible plagues because of Sarai, Abram's wife.
12.18: Then Pharaoh called for Abram. "What have you done to me?" he asked. "Why didn't you tell me that she's your wife?
12.19: Why did you say, 'She's my sister' and allow me to take her for my wife? Here's your wife! Take her and go!"
12.20: Pharaoh gave his men orders concerning Abram. They sent Abram away with his wife and everything that he had.

13.1: Abram left Egypt with his wife and everything he had and went to the Negev. Lot was with him.
13.2: Abram was very rich because he had livestock, silver, and gold.
13.3: He traveled from place to place. He went from the Negev as far as Bethel, to the area between Bethel and Ai where his tent had been originally,
13.4: where he had first made an altar. There Abram worshiped the LORD.
13.5: Lot, who had been traveling with Abram, also had his own sheep, cattle, and tents.
13.6: There wasn't enough pastureland for both of them. They had so many possessions that they were unable to remain together.
13.7: Quarrels broke out between Abram's herders and Lot's herders. (Canaanites and Perizzites were also living in that area.)
13.8: Abram said to Lot, "Please, let's not have any more quarrels between us or between our herders. After all, we're relatives.
13.9: Isn't all this land yours also? Let's separate. If you go to the left, I'll go to the right, and if you go to the right, I'll go to the left."
13.10: Then Lot looked in the direction of Zoar as far as he could see. He saw that the whole Jordan Plain was well-watered like the LORD's garden or like Egypt. (This was before the LORD destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
13.11: Lot chose the whole Jordan Plain for himself. He moved toward the east. They each went their own way.
13.12: Abram lived in Canaan, while Lot lived among the cities of the plain, moving his tents as far as Sodom.
13.13: (The people who lived in Sodom were very wicked. They committed terrible sins against the LORD.)
13.14: After Lot left, the LORD said to Abram, "Look north, south, east, and west of where you are.
13.15: I will give all the land you see to you and to your descendants for an indefinite period of time.
13.16: I will also give you as many descendants as the dust of the earth. If anyone could count the dust of the earth, then he could also count your descendants.
13.17: Go! Walk back and forth across the entire land because I will give it to you."
13.18: So Abram moved his tents and went to live by the oak trees belonging to Mamre at Hebron. There he built an altar for the LORD.

14.1: At that time [four kings]-King Amraphel of Shinar, King Arioch of Ellasar, King Chedorlaomer of Elam, and King Tidal of Goiim-
14.2: went to war against [five kings]-King Bera of Sodom, King Birsha of Gomorrah, King Shinab of Admah, King Shemeber of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).
14.3: The five kings joined forces and met in the valley of Siddim (that is, the Dead Sea).
14.4: For 12 years they had been subject to Chedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
14.5: In the fourteenth year Chedorlaomer and his allies came and defeated the Rephaim at Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzim at Ham, the Emim at Shaveh Kiriathaim,
14.6: and the Horites in the hill country of Seir, going as far as El Paran on the edge of the desert.
14.7: On their way back, they came to En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh), and they conquered the whole territory of the Amalekites and also the Amorites who were living at Hazazon Tamar.
14.8: Then the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela (that is, Zoar) marched out and prepared for battle in the valley of Siddim.
14.9: They fought against King Chedorlaomer of Elam, King Tidal of Goiim, King Amraphel of Shinar, and King Arioch of Ellasar-four kings against five.
14.10: The valley of Siddim was full of tar pits. As the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, they fell because of the tar pits, but the other kings fled to the hills.
14.11: So the four kings took all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah, as well as all their food, and left.
14.12: They also took Abram's nephew Lot and his possessions since he was living in Sodom.
14.13: Then a soldier who had escaped came and told Abram the Hebrew what had happened. He was living next to the oak trees belonging to Mamre the Amorite, a brother of Eshcol and Aner. (These men were Abram's allies.)
14.14: When Abram heard that his nephew had been captured, he armed his 318 trained men, born in his own household, and pursued the four kings all the way to Dan.
14.15: He split up his men to attack them at night. He defeated them, pursuing them all the way to Hobah, which is north of Damascus.
14.16: He brought back everything they had, including women and soldiers. He also brought back his relative Lot and his possessions.
14.17: After Abram came back from defeating Chedorlaomer and his allies, the king of Sodom came out to meet him in the Shaveh Valley (that is, the King's Valley).
14.18: Then King Melchizedek of Salem brought out bread and wine. He was a priest of God Most High.
14.19: He blessed Abram, and said, "Blessed is Abram by God Most High, maker of heaven and earth.
14.20: Blessed is God Most High, who has handed your enemies over to you." Then Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
14.21: The king of Sodom said to Abram, "Give me the people, and keep everything else for yourself."
14.22: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, "I now raise my hand and solemnly swear to the LORD God Most High, maker of heaven and earth,
14.23: that I won't take a thread or a sandal strap. I won't take anything that is yours so that you will never be able to say, 'I made Abram rich.'
14.24: I won't take one single thing except what my men have eaten. But let my allies Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre take their share."

15.1: Later the LORD spoke his word to Abram in a vision. He said, "Abram, don't be afraid. I am your shield. Your reward will be very great."
15.2: Abram asked, "Almighty LORD, what will you give me? Since I'm going to die without children, Eliezer of Damascus will inherit my household.
15.3: You have given me no children, so this member of my household will be my heir."
15.4: Suddenly, the LORD spoke his word to Abram again. He said, "This man will not be your heir. Your own son will be your heir."
15.5: He took Abram outside and said, "Now look up at the sky and count the stars, if you are able to count them." He also said to him, "That's how many descendants you will have!"
15.6: Then Abram believed the LORD, and the LORD regarded that faith to be his approval of Abram.
15.7: Then the LORD said to him, "I am the LORD, who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land so that you will take possession of it."
15.8: Abram asked, "Almighty LORD, how can I be certain that I will take possession of it?"
15.9: He answered Abram, "Bring me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a mourning dove, and a pigeon."
15.10: So Abram brought all these animals to him. He cut each of them in half and laid each half opposite the other. However, he did not cut the birds in half.
15.11: When birds of prey came down upon the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
15.12: As the sun was just about to set, a deep sleep-a dreadful, deep darkness-came over Abram.
15.13: God said to Abram, "You can know for sure that your descendants will live in a land that is not their own, where they will be slaves, and they will be oppressed for 400 years.
15.14: But I will punish the nation they serve, and after that they will come out with many possessions.
15.15: But you will die in peace and be buried at a very old age.
15.16: In the fourth generation your descendants will come back here, because the sin of the Amorites will not have run its course until then."
15.17: The sun had gone down, and it was dark. Suddenly a smoking oven and a flaming torch passed between the animal pieces.
15.18: At that time the LORD made a promise to Abram. He said, "I will give this land to your descendants. This is the land from the river of Egypt to the great river, the Euphrates.
15.19: It is the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
15.20: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaim,
15.21: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites."

16.1: Sarai, Abram's wife, was not able to have children. She owned an Egyptian slave named Hagar.
16.2: So Sarai said to Abram, "The LORD has kept me from having children. Why don't you sleep with my slave? Maybe I can build a family through her." Abram agreed with Sarai.
16.3: After Abram had lived in Canaan for ten years, Abram's wife Sarai took her Egyptian slave Hagar and gave her to her husband Abram to be his wife.
16.4: He slept with Hagar, and she became pregnant. When Hagar realized that she was pregnant, she began to be disrespectful to Sarai, her owner.
16.5: So Sarai complained to Abram, "I'm being treated unfairly! And it's your fault! I know that I gave my slave to you, but now that she's pregnant, she's being disrespectful to me. May the LORD decide who is right-you or me."
16.6: Abram answered Sarai, "Here, she's your slave. Do what you like with her." Then Sarai mistreated Hagar so much that she ran away.
16.7: The Messenger of the LORD found her by a spring in the desert, the spring on the way to Shur.
16.8: He said, "Hagar, Sarai's slave, where have you come from, and where are you going?" She answered, "I'm running away from my owner Sarai."
16.9: The Messenger of the LORD said to her, "Go back to your owner, and place yourself under her authority."
16.10: The Messenger of the LORD also said to her, "I will give you many descendants. No one will be able to count them because there will be so many."
16.11: Then the Messenger of the LORD said to her, "You are pregnant, and you will give birth to a son. You will name him Ishmael [God Hears], because the LORD has heard your cry of distress.
16.12: He will be as free and wild as an untamed donkey. He will fight with everyone, and everyone will fight with him. He will have conflicts with all his relatives."
16.13: Hagar named the LORD, who had been speaking to her, "You Are the God Who Watches Over Me." She said, "This is the place where I watched [the one] who watches over me."
16.14: This is why the well is named Beer Lahai Roi [Well of the Living One Who Watches Over Me]. It is still there between Kadesh and Bered.
16.15: Hagar gave birth to Abram's son. Abram named him Ishmael.
16.16: Abram was 86 years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael.

17.1: When Abram was 99 years old, the LORD appeared to him. He said to Abram, "I am God Almighty. Live in my presence with integrity.
17.2: I will give you my promise, and I will give you very many descendants."
17.3: Immediately, Abram bowed with his face touching the ground, and again God spoke to him,
17.4: "My promise is still with you. You will become the father of many nations.
17.5: So your name will no longer be Abram [Exalted Father], but Abraham [Father of Many] because I have made you a father of many nations.
17.6: I will give you many descendants. Many nations and kings will come from you.
17.7: I will make my promise to you and your descendants for generations to come as an everlasting promise. I will be your God and the God of your descendants.
17.8: I am also giving this land where you are living-all of Canaan-to you and your descendants as your permanent possession. And I will be your God."
17.9: God also said to Abraham, "You and your descendants in generations to come are to be faithful to my promise.
17.10: This is how you are to be faithful to my promise: Every male among you is to be circumcised.
17.11: All of you must be circumcised. That will be the sign of the promise from me to you.
17.12: For generations to come every male child who is eight days old must be circumcised, whether he is born in your household or bought with money from a foreigner who's not related to you.
17.13: Every male born in your household or bought with your money is to be circumcised without exception. So my promise will be a sign on your flesh, an everlasting promise.
17.14: Any uncircumcised male must be excluded from his people because he has rejected my promise."
17.15: God said to Abraham, "Don't call your wife by the name Sarai anymore. Instead, her name is Sarah [Princess].
17.16: I will bless her, and I will also give you a son by her. I will bless her, and she will become [a mother of] nations, and kings will come from her."
17.17: Immediately, Abraham bowed with his face touching the ground. He laughed as he thought to himself, "Can a son be born to a hundred-year-old man? Can Sarah, a ninety-year-old woman, have a child?"
17.18: Then Abraham said to God, "Why not let Ishmael be my heir?"
17.19: God replied, "No! Your wife Sarah will give you a son, and you will name him Isaac [He Laughs]. I will make an everlasting promise to him and his descendants.
17.20: I have heard your request about Ishmael. Yes, I will bless him, make him fertile, and increase the number of his descendants. He will be the father of 12 princes, and I will make him a great nation.
17.21: But I will make my promise to Isaac. Sarah will give birth to him at this time next year."
17.22: When God finished speaking with Abraham, he left him.
17.23: So Abraham took his son Ishmael, everyone born in his household, and everyone bought with money-every male in his household-and circumcised them that day, as God had told him.
17.24: Abraham was 99 years old when he was circumcised.
17.25: His son Ishmael was 13 years old when he was circumcised.
17.26: That same day Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised.
17.27: All the men of his household, whether born in the household or bought with money from a foreigner, were circumcised with him.

18.1: The LORD appeared to Abraham by the oak trees belonging to Mamre as he was sitting at the entrance of his tent during the hottest part of the day.
18.2: Abraham looked up, and suddenly he saw three men standing near him. When he saw them, he ran to meet them, and he bowed with his face touching the ground.
18.3: "Please, sir," Abraham said, "stop by to visit me for a while.
18.4: Why don't we let someone bring a little water? After you wash your feet, you can stretch out and rest under the tree.
18.5: Let me bring some bread so that you can regain your strength. After that you can leave, since this is why you stopped by to visit me." They answered, "That's fine. Do as you say."
18.6: So Abraham hurried into the tent to find Sarah. "Quick," he said, "get three measures of flour, knead it, and make bread."
18.7: Then Abraham ran to the herd and took one of his best calves. He gave it to his servant, who prepared it quickly.
18.8: Abraham took cheese and milk, as well as the meat, and set these in front of them. Then he stood by them under the tree as they ate.
18.9: They asked him, "Where is your wife Sarah?" He answered, "Over there, in the tent."
18.10: The LORD said, "I promise I'll come back to you next year at this time, and your wife Sarah will have a son." Sarah happened to be listening at the entrance of the tent, which was behind him.
18.11: Abraham and Sarah were old. Sarah was past the age of childbearing.
18.12: And so Sarah laughed to herself, thinking, "Now that I've become old, will I enjoy myself again? What's more, my husband is old!"
18.13: The LORD asked Abraham, "Why did Sarah laugh and say, 'Can I really have a child now that I'm old?'
18.14: Is anything too hard for the LORD? I will come back to you next year at this time, and Sarah will have a son."
18.15: Because she was afraid, Sarah denied that she had laughed. But the LORD said, "Yes, you did laugh."
18.16: Then the men got up to leave. As Abraham was walking with them to see them off, they looked toward Sodom.
18.17: The LORD said, "I shouldn't hide what I am going to do from Abraham.
18.18: After all, Abraham is going to become a great and mighty nation and through him all the nations of the earth will be blessed.
18.19: I have chosen him so that he will direct his children and his family after him to keep the way of the LORD by doing what is right and just. In this way I, the LORD, will do what I have promised Abraham."
18.20: The LORD also said, "Sodom and Gomorrah have many complaints against them, and their sin is very serious.
18.21: I must go down and see whether these complaints are true. If not, I will know it."
18.22: From there the men turned and went on toward Sodom, but Abraham remained standing in front of the LORD.
18.23: Abraham came closer and asked, "Are you really going to sweep away the innocent with the guilty?
18.24: What if there are 50 innocent people in the city? Are you really going to sweep them away? Won't you spare that place for the sake of the 50 innocent people who are in it?
18.25: It would be unthinkable for you to do such a thing, to treat the innocent and the guilty alike and to kill the innocent with the guilty. That would be unthinkable! Won't the judge of the whole earth do what is fair?"
18.26: The LORD said, "If I find 50 innocent people inside the city of Sodom, I will spare the whole place for their sake."
18.27: Abraham asked, "Consider now, if I may be so bold as to ask you, although I'm [only] dust and ashes,
18.28: what if there are 45 innocent people? Will you destroy the whole city because of 5 fewer people?" The LORD answered, "I will not destroy it if I find 45 there."
18.29: Abraham asked him again, "What if 40 are found there?" He answered, "For the sake of the 40 I will not do it."
18.30: "Please don't be angry if I speak again," Abraham said. "What if 30 are found there?" He answered, "If I find 30 there, I will not do it."
18.31: "Look now, if I may be so bold as to ask you," Abraham said. "What if 20 are found there?" He answered, "I will not destroy it for the sake of the 20."
18.32: "Please don't be angry if I speak only one more time," Abraham said. "What if 10 are found there?" He answered, "I will not destroy it for the sake of the 10."
18.33: When the LORD finished speaking to Abraham, he left. Abraham returned home.

19.1: The two angels came to Sodom in the evening as Lot was sitting in the gateway. When Lot saw them, he got up to meet them and bowed with his face touching the ground.
19.2: He said, "Please, gentlemen, why don't you come to my home and spend the night? [You can] wash your feet there. Then early tomorrow morning you can continue your journey." "No," they answered, "we'd rather spend the night in the city square."
19.3: But he insisted so strongly that they came with him and went into his home. He prepared a special dinner for them, baked some unleavened bread, and they ate.
19.4: Before they had gone to bed, all the young and old male citizens of Sodom surrounded the house.
19.5: They called to Lot, "Where are the men who came to [stay with] you tonight? Bring them out to us so that we can have sex with them."
19.6: Then Lot went outside and shut the door behind him.
19.7: "Please, my friends, don't be so wicked," he said.
19.8: "Look, I have two daughters who have never had sex. Why don't you let me bring them out to you? Do whatever you like with them. But don't do anything to these men, since I'm responsible for them."
19.9: But the men yelled, "Get out of the way! This man came here to stay awhile. Now he wants to be our judge! We're going to treat you worse than those men." They pushed hard against Lot and lunged forward to break down the door.
19.10: The men [inside] reached out, pulled Lot into the house with them, and shut the door.
19.11: Then they struck all the men who were in the doorway of the house, young and old alike, with blindness so that they gave up trying to find the door.
19.12: Then the men asked Lot, "Do you have anyone else here-any in-laws, sons, daughters, or any other relatives in the city? Get them out of here
19.13: because we're going to destroy this place. The complaints to the LORD against its people are so loud that the LORD has sent us to destroy it."
19.14: So Lot went out and spoke to the men engaged to his daughters. He said, "Hurry! Get out of this place, because the LORD is going to destroy the city." But they thought he was joking.
19.15: As soon as it was dawn, the angels urged Lot by saying, "Quick! Take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or you'll be swept away when the city is punished."
19.16: When he hesitated, the men grabbed him, his wife, and his two daughters by their hands, because the LORD wanted to spare Lot. They brought them safely outside the city.
19.17: As soon as they were outside, one [of the angels] said, "Run for your lives! Don't look behind you, and don't stop on the plain. Run for the hills, or you'll be swept away!"
19.19: Even though you've been so good to me and though you've been very kind to me by saving my life, I can't run as far as the hills. This disaster will overtake me, and I'll die.
19.20: Look, there's a city near enough to flee to, and it's small. Why don't you let me run there? Isn't it small? Then my life will be saved."
19.21: The angel said to him, "Alright, I will grant you this request too. I will not destroy the city you're talking about.
19.22: Run there quickly, because I can't do anything until you get there." (The city is named Zoar [Small].)
19.23: The sun had just risen over the land as Lot came to Zoar.
19.24: Then the LORD made burning sulfur and fire rain out of heaven on Sodom and Gomorrah.
19.25: He destroyed those cities, the whole plain, all who lived in the cities, and whatever grew on the ground.
19.26: Lot's wife looked back and turned into a column of salt.
19.27: Early the next morning Abraham came to the place where he had stood in front of the LORD.
19.28: When he looked toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the land in the plain, he saw smoke rising from the land like the thick smoke of a furnace.
19.29: When God destroyed the cities on the plain, he remembered Abraham. Lot was allowed to escape from the destruction that came to the cities where he was living.
19.30: Lot left Zoar because he was afraid to stay there. He and his two daughters settled in the mountains where they lived in a cave.
19.31: The older daughter said to the younger one, "Our father is old. No men are here. We can't get married as other people do.
19.32: Let's give our father wine to drink. Then we'll go to bed with him so that we'll be able to preserve our family line through our father."
19.33: That night they gave their father wine to drink. Then the older one went to bed with her father. He didn't know when she came to bed or when she got up.
19.34: The next day the older daughter said to the younger one, "I did it! Last night I went to bed with my father. Let's give him wine to drink again tonight. Then you go to bed with him so that we'll be able to preserve our family line through our father."
19.35: That night they gave their father wine to drink again. Then the younger one went to bed with him. He didn't know when she came to bed or when she got up.
19.36: So Lot's two daughters became pregnant by their father.
19.37: The older one gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the ancestor of the Moabites of today.
19.38: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben Ammi. He is the ancestor of the Ammonites of today.

20.1: Abraham moved to the Negev and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While he was living in Gerar,
20.2: Abraham told everyone that his wife Sarah was his sister. So King Abimelech of Gerar sent men to take Sarah.
20.3: God came to Abimelech in a dream one night and said to him, "You're going to die because of the woman that you've taken! She's a married woman!"
20.4: Abimelech hadn't come near her, so he asked, "Lord, will you destroy a nation even if it's innocent?
20.5: Didn't he tell me himself, 'She's my sister,' and didn't she even say, 'He's my brother'? I did this in all innocence and with a clear conscience."
20.6: "Yes, I know that you did this with a clear conscience," God said to him in the dream. "In fact, I kept you from sinning against me. That's why I didn't let you touch her.
20.7: Give the man's wife back to him now, because he's a prophet. He will pray for you, and you will live. But if you don't give her back, you and all who belong to you are doomed to die."
20.8: Early in the morning Abimelech called together all his officials. He told them about all of this, and they were terrified.
20.9: Then Abimelech called for Abraham and asked him, "What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you that you would bring such a serious sin on me and my kingdom? You shouldn't have done this to me."
20.10: Abimelech also asked Abraham, "What were you thinking when you did this?"
20.11: Abraham said, "I thought that because there are no God-fearing people in this place, I'd be killed because of my wife.
20.12: Besides, she is my sister-my father's daughter but not my mother's. She is also my wife.
20.13: When God had me leave my father's home and travel around, I said to her, 'Do me a favor: Wherever we go, say that I'm your brother.'"
20.14: Then Abimelech took sheep, cattle, and male and female slaves and gave them to Abraham. He also gave his wife Sarah back to him.
20.15: Abimelech said, "Look, here's my land. Live anywhere you like."
20.16: He said to Sarah, "Don't forget, I've given your brother 25 pounds of silver. This is to silence any criticism against you from everyone with you. You're completely cleared."
20.17: Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female slaves so that they could have children.
20.18: (The LORD had made it impossible for any woman in Abimelech's household to have children because of Abraham's wife Sarah.)

21.1: The LORD came to help Sarah and did for her what he had promised.
21.2: So she became pregnant, and at the exact time God had promised, she gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age.
21.3: Abraham named his newborn son Isaac.
21.4: When Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him as God had commanded.
21.5: Abraham was 100 years old when his son Isaac was born.
21.6: Sarah said, "God has brought me laughter, and everyone who hears about this will laugh with me.
21.7: Who would have predicted to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet, I have given him a son in his old age."
21.8: The child grew and was weaned. On the day Isaac was weaned, Abraham held a big feast.
21.9: Sarah saw that Abraham's son by Hagar the Egyptian was laughing at Isaac.
21.10: She said to Abraham, "Get rid of this slave and her son, because this slave's son must never share the inheritance with my son Isaac."
21.11: Abraham was upset by this because of his son Ishmael.
21.12: But God said to Abraham, "Don't be upset about the boy and your slave. Listen to what Sarah says because through Isaac your descendants will carry on your name.
21.13: Besides, I will make the slave's son into a nation also, because he is your child."
21.14: Early the next morning Abraham took bread and a container of water and gave them to Hagar, putting them on her shoulder. He also gave her the boy and sent her on her way. So she left and wandered around in the desert near Beersheba.
21.15: When the water in the container was gone, she put the boy under one of the bushes.
21.16: Then she went about as far away as an arrow can be shot and sat down. She said to herself, "I don't want to watch the boy die." So she sat down and sobbed loudly.
21.17: God heard the boy crying, and the Messenger of God called to Hagar from heaven. "What's the matter, Hagar?" he asked her. "Don't be afraid! God has heard the boy crying from the bushes.
21.18: Come on, help the boy up! Take him by the hand, because I'm going to make him into a great nation."
21.19: God opened her eyes. Then she saw a well. She filled the container with water and gave the boy a drink.
21.20: God was with the boy as he grew up. He lived in the desert and became a skilled archer.
21.21: He lived in the desert of Paran, and his mother got him a wife from Egypt.
21.22: At that time Abimelech, accompanied by Phicol, the commander of his army, said to Abraham, "God is with you in everything you do.
21.23: Now, swear an oath to me here in front of God that you will never cheat me, my children, or my descendants. Show me and the land where you've been living the same kindness that I have shown you."
21.25: Then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well which Abimelech's servants had seized.
21.26: Abimelech replied, "I don't know who did this. You didn't tell me, and I didn't hear about it until today."
21.27: Abraham took some sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech, and the two of them made an agreement.
21.28: Then Abraham set apart seven female lambs from the flock.
21.29: Abimelech asked him, "What is the meaning of these seven female lambs you have set apart?"
21.30: Abraham answered, "Accept these lambs from me so that they may be proof that I dug this well."
21.31: This is why that place is called Beersheba, because both of them swore an oath there.
21.32: After they made the treaty at Beersheba, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, left and went back to the land of the Philistines.
21.33: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree at Beersheba and worshiped the LORD, the Everlasting God, there.
21.34: Abraham lived a long time in the land of the Philistines.

22.1: Later God tested Abraham and called to him, "Abraham!" "Yes, here I am!" he answered.
22.2: God said, "Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains that I will show you."
22.3: Early the next morning Abraham saddled his donkey. He took with him two of his servants and his son Isaac. When he had cut the wood for the burnt offering, he set out for the place that God had told him about.
22.4: Two days later Abraham saw the place in the distance.
22.5: Then Abraham said to his servants, "You stay here with the donkey while the boy and I go over there. We'll worship. After that we'll come back to you."
22.6: Then Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and gave it to his son Isaac. Abraham carried the burning coals and the knife. The two of them went on together.
22.7: Isaac spoke up and said, "Father?" "Yes, Son?" Abraham answered. Isaac asked, "We have the burning coals and the wood, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?"
22.8: Abraham answered, "God will provide a lamb for the burnt offering, Son." The two of them went on together.
22.9: When they came to the place that God had told him about, Abraham built the altar and arranged the wood on it. Then he tied up his son Isaac and laid him on top of the wood on the altar.
22.10: Next, Abraham picked up the knife and took it in his hand to sacrifice his son.
22.11: But the Messenger of the LORD called to him from heaven and said, "Abraham! Abraham!" "Yes?" he answered.
22.12: "Do not lay a hand on the boy," he said. "Do not do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, because you did not refuse to give me your son, your only son."
22.13: When Abraham looked around, he saw a ram behind him caught by its horns in a bush. So Abraham took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering in place of his son.
22.14: Abraham named that place The LORD Will Provide. It is still said today, "On the mountain of the LORD it will be provided."
22.15: Then the Messenger of the LORD called to Abraham from heaven a second time
22.16: and said, "I am taking an oath on my own name, declares the LORD, that because you have done this and have not refused to give me your son, your only son,
22.17: I will certainly bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and the grains of sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of their enemies' cities.
22.18: Through your descendant all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed me."
22.19: Then Abraham returned to his servants, and together they left for Beersheba. Abraham remained in Beersheba.
22.20: Later Abraham was told, "Milcah has given birth to these children of your brother Nahor:
22.21: Uz (the firstborn), Buz (his brother), Kemuel (father of Aram),
22.22: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.
22.23: Bethuel is the father of Rebekah. Milcah had these eight sons by Abraham's brother Nahor.
22.24: Nahor's concubine, whose name was Reumah, had the following children: Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah."

23.1: Sarah lived to be 127 years old. This was the length of her life.
23.2: She died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in Canaan. Abraham went to mourn for Sarah and to cry about her death.
23.3: Then Abraham left the side of his dead wife and spoke to the Hittites,
23.4: "I'm a stranger with no permanent home. Let me have some of your property for a tomb so that I can bury my dead wife."
23.6: "Listen to us, sir. You are a mighty leader among us. Bury your dead in one of our best tombs. Not one of us will withhold from you his tomb for burying your dead."
23.7: Abraham got up in front of the Hittites, the people of that region, and bowed with his face touching the ground.
23.8: He said to them, "If you are willing to let me bury my wife, listen to me. Encourage Ephron, son of Zohar,
23.9: to let me have the cave of Machpelah that he owns at the end of his field. He should sell it to me for its full price as my property to be used as a tomb among you."
23.10: Ephron was sitting among the Hittites. He answered Abraham so that everyone who was entering the city gate could hear him. He said,
23.11: "No, sir, listen to me. I'm giving you the field together with the cave that is in it. My people are witnesses that I'm giving it to you. Bury your wife!"
23.12: Abraham bowed down again in front of the people of that region.
23.13: He spoke to Ephron so that the people of that region could hear him. He said, "If you would only listen to me. I will pay you the price of the field. Take it from me so that I can bury my wife there."
23.15: "Sir, listen to me. The land is worth ten pounds of silver. What is that between us? Bury your wife!"
23.16: Abraham agreed to Ephron's terms. So he weighed out for Ephron the amount stated in front of the Hittites: ten pounds of silver at the current merchants' exchange rate.
23.17: So Ephron's field at Machpelah, east of Mamre, was sold
23.18: to Abraham. His property included the field with the cave in it as well as all the trees inside the boundaries of the field. The Hittites together with all who had entered the city gate were the official witnesses for the agreement.
23.19: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre (that is, Hebron).
23.20: So the field and its cave were sold by the Hittites to Abraham as his property to be used as a tomb.

24.1: By now Abraham was old, and the LORD had blessed him in every way.
24.2: So Abraham said to the senior servant of his household who was in charge of all that he owned, "Take a solemn oath.
24.3: I want you to swear by the LORD God of heaven and earth that you will not get my son a wife from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom I'm living.
24.4: Instead, you will go to the land of my relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac."
24.5: The servant asked him, "What if the woman doesn't want to come back to this land with me? Should I take your son all the way back to the land you came from?"
24.6: "Make sure that you do not take my son back there," Abraham said to him.
24.7: "The LORD God of heaven took me from my father's home and the land of my family. He spoke to me and swore this oath: 'I will give this land to your descendants.' "God will send his angel ahead of you, and you will get my son a wife from there.
24.8: If the woman doesn't want to come back with you, then you'll be free from this oath that you swear to me. But don't take my son back there."
24.9: So the servant did as his master Abraham commanded and swore the oath to him concerning this.
24.10: Then the servant took ten of his master's camels and left, taking with him all of his master's best things. He traveled to Aram Naharaim, Nahor's city.
24.11: The servant had the camels kneel down outside the city by the well. It was evening, when the women would go out to draw water.
24.12: Then he prayed, "LORD, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today. Show your kindness to Abraham.
24.13: Here I am standing by the spring, and the girls of the city are coming out to draw water.
24.14: I will ask a girl, 'May I please have a drink from your jar?' If she answers, 'Have a drink, and I'll also water your camels,' let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. This way I'll know that you've shown your kindness to my master."
24.15: Before he had finished praying, Rebekah came with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, who was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.
24.16: The girl was a very attractive virgin. No man had ever had sexual intercourse with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar, and came back.
24.17: The servant ran to meet her and said, "Please give me a drink of water."
24.18: "Drink, sir," she said. She quickly lowered her jar to her hand and gave him a drink.
24.19: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, "I'll also keep drawing water for your camels until they've had enough to drink."
24.20: So she quickly emptied her jar into the water trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
24.21: The man was silently watching her to see whether or not the LORD had made his trip successful.
24.22: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a fifth of an ounce and two gold bracelets weighing four ounces.
24.23: He asked, "Whose daughter are you? Please tell me whether there is room in your father's house for us to spend the night."
24.24: She answered him, "I'm the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah and Nahor.
24.25: We have plenty of straw and feed [for your camels] and room for you to spend the night."
24.26: The man knelt, bowing to the LORD with his face touching the ground.
24.27: He said, "Praise the LORD, the God of my master Abraham. The LORD hasn't failed to be kind and faithful to my master. The LORD has led me on this trip to the home of my master's relatives."
24.28: The girl ran and told her mother's household about these things.
24.29: Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban.
24.30: He saw the nose ring and the bracelets on his sister's wrists and heard her tell what the man had said to her. Immediately, Laban ran out to the man by the spring. He came to the man, who was standing with the camels by the spring.
24.31: He said, "Come in, you whom the LORD has blessed. Why are you standing out here? I have straightened up the house and made a place for the camels."
24.32: So the man went into the house. The camels were unloaded and given straw and feed. Then water was brought for him and his men to wash their feet.
24.33: When the food was put in front of him, he said, "I won't eat until I've said what I have to say." "Speak up," Laban said.
24.35: "The LORD has blessed my master, and he has become wealthy. The LORD has given him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female slaves, camels and donkeys.
24.36: My master's wife Sarah gave him a son in her old age, and my master has given that son everything he has.
24.37: My master made me swear this oath: 'Don't get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I'm living.
24.38: Instead, go to my father's home and to my relatives, and get my son a wife.'
24.39: "I asked my master, 'What if the woman won't come back with me?'
24.40: "He answered me, 'I have been living the way the LORD wants me to. The LORD will send his angel with you to make your trip successful. You will get my son a wife from my relatives and from my father's family.
24.41: Then you will be free from your oath to me. You will also be free of your oath to me if my relatives are not willing to do this when you go to them.'
24.42: "When I came to the spring today, I prayed, 'LORD God of my master Abraham, please make my trip successful.
24.43: I'm standing by the spring. I'll say to the young woman who comes out to draw water, "Please give me a drink of water."
24.44: If she says to me, "Not only may you have a drink, but I will also draw water for your camels," let her be the woman the LORD has chosen for my master's son.'
24.45: "Before I had finished praying, Rebekah came with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water. "So I asked her, 'May I have a drink?'
24.46: She quickly lowered her jar and said, 'Have a drink, and I'll water your camels too.' So I drank, and she also watered the camels.
24.47: "Then I asked her, 'Whose daughter are you?' "She answered, 'The daughter of Bethuel, son of Nahor and Milcah.' "I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her wrists.
24.48: I knelt, bowing down to the LORD. I praised the LORD, the God of my master Abraham. The LORD led me in the right direction to get the daughter of my master's relative for his son.
24.49: Tell me whether or not you're going to show my master true kindness so that I will know what to do."
24.50: Laban and Bethuel answered, "This is from the LORD. We can't say anything to you one way or another.
24.51: Here's Rebekah! Take her and go! She will become the wife of your master's son, as the LORD has said."
24.52: When Abraham's servant heard their answer, he bowed down to the LORD.
24.53: The servant took out gold and silver jewelry and clothes and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave expensive presents to her brother and mother.
24.54: Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank and spent the night. When they got up in the morning, he said, "Let me go back to my master."
24.55: Her brother and mother replied, "Let the girl stay with us ten days or so. After that she may go."
24.56: He said to them, "Don't delay me now that the LORD has made my trip successful. Let me go back to my master."
24.57: So they said, "We'll call the girl and ask her."
24.58: They called for Rebekah and asked her, "Will you go with this man?" She said, "Yes, I'll go."
24.59: So they let their sister Rebekah and her nurse go with Abraham's servant and his men.
24.60: They gave Rebekah a blessing: "May you, our sister, become the mother of many thousands of children. May your descendants take possession of their enemies' cities."
24.61: Then Rebekah and her maids left. Riding on camels, they followed the man. The servant took Rebekah and left.
24.62: Isaac had just come back from Beer Lahai Roi, since he was living in the Negev.
24.63: Toward evening Isaac went out into the field to meditate. When he looked up, he saw camels coming.
24.64: When Rebekah saw Isaac, she got down from her camel.
24.65: She asked the servant, "Who is that man over there coming through the field to meet us?" "That is my master," the servant answered. Then she took her veil and covered herself.
24.66: The servant reported to Isaac everything he had done.
24.67: Isaac took her into his mother Sarah's tent. He married Rebekah. She became his wife, and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother's death.

25.1: Abraham married again, and his wife's name was Keturah.
25.2: Keturah gave birth to these sons of Abraham: Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
25.3: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. Dedan's descendants were the Assyrians, the Letushites, and the Leummites.
25.4: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. These were the descendants of Keturah.
25.5: Abraham left everything he had to Isaac.
25.6: But while he was still living, Abraham had given gifts to the sons of his concubines. He sent them away from his son Isaac to a land in the east.
25.8: Then he took his last breath, and died at a very old age. After a long and full life, he joined his ancestors in death.
25.9: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah in the field of Ephron, son of Zohar the Hittite. The cave is east of Mamre.
25.10: This was the field that Abraham had bought from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
25.11: After Abraham died, God blessed his son Isaac, who settled near Beer Lahai Roi.
25.12: This is the account of the descendants of Abraham's son Ishmael. He was the son of Sarah's Egyptian slave Hagar and Abraham.
25.13: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael listed in the order of their birth: Nebaioth (Ishmael's firstborn), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
25.15: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
25.16: These are the sons of Ishmael and their names listed by their settlements and camps-12 leaders of their tribes.
25.17: Ishmael lived 137 years. Then he took his last breath and died. He joined his ancestors in death.
