23.9: I see them from the top of rocky cliffs, I look at them from the hills. I see a nation that lives by itself, people who do not consider themselves to be like other nations.
23.10: The descendants of Jacob are like specks of dust. Who can count them or number even one-fourth of the people of Israel? Let me die the death of innocent people. Let my end be like theirs."
23.11: Balak said to Balaam, "What have you done to me? I brought you here to curse my enemies, but all you've done is bless them!"
23.12: Balaam answered, "I must say what the LORD tells me to say."
23.13: Then Balak said to him, "Please come with me to another place, where you can see the Israelites. You will see only some of them, not all of them. Curse them for me from there."
23.14: So he took him to the Field of Zophim on top of Mount Pisgah, where he built seven altars. He offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.15: Then Balaam said to Balak, "Stay here beside your burnt offering while I meet with God over there."
23.16: The LORD came to Balaam and told him, "Go back to Balak, and give him my message."
23.17: He came to Balak and found him standing beside his burnt offering with the princes of Moab. Balak asked him, "What did the LORD say?"
23.18: Then Balaam delivered this message: "Stand up, Balak, and listen! Hear me, son of Zippor!
23.19: God is not like people. He tells no lies. He is not like humans. He doesn't change his mind. When he says something, he does it. When he makes a promise, he keeps it.
23.20: I have received a command to bless. He has blessed, and I can't change it.
23.21: He doesn't want any trouble for the descendants of Jacob. He sees no misfortune for the people of Israel. The LORD their God is with them, praised as their king.
23.22: The God who brought them out of Egypt has the strength of a wild bull.
23.23: No spell can curse the descendants of Jacob. No magic can harm the people of Israel. Now it will be said of Jacob and Israel: 'See what God has done!'
23.24: Here is a nation that attacks like a lioness and is as ferocious as a lion. It doesn't lie down until it eats its prey and drinks the blood of its victim."
23.25: Balak said to Balaam, "If you won't curse them, then at least don't bless them!"
23.26: Balaam answered, "Didn't I tell you that I must do whatever the LORD says?"
23.27: Balak said to Balaam, "Come, let me take you to another place. Maybe God wants you to curse them for me from there."
23.28: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, which overlooks Jeshimon.
23.29: Balaam said to Balak, "Build seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me."
23.30: Balak did what Balaam told him, and he offered a bull and a ram on each altar.

24.1: When Balaam saw that the LORD wanted to bless Israel, he didn't look for omens as he had done before. He turned toward the desert,
24.2: looked up, and saw Israel's camp grouped by tribes. The Spirit of God entered him,
24.3: and he delivered this message: "This is the message of Balaam, son of Beor. This is the message of the man whose eyesight is clear.
24.4: This is the message of the one who hears the words of God, has a vision from the Almighty, and falls [into a trance] with his eyes open:
24.5: How beautiful are your tents, Jacob, and the places where you live, Israel.
24.6: Your tents spread out like rivers, like gardens by a river, like aloes planted by the LORD, like cedars by the water.
24.7: Water will flow from their buckets, and their crops will have plenty of water. Their king will be greater than Agag, and their kingdom will be considered the best.
24.8: The God who brought them out of Egypt has the strength of a wild bull. He will devour nations that are his enemies, crush their bones, and pierce them with arrows.
24.9: His people lie down [and] rest like a lion. They are like a lioness. Who dares to disturb them? Those who bless you will be blessed! Those who curse you will be cursed!"
24.10: Balak became angry with Balaam. He clapped his hands and said, "I summoned you to curse my enemies, and now you have blessed them three times.
24.11: Get out of here! Go home! I said I'd reward you richly, but the LORD has made you lose your reward."
24.12: Balaam answered Balak, "I told the messengers you sent me,
24.13: 'Even if Balak would give me his palace filled with silver and gold, I couldn't disobey the LORD's command no matter how good or bad the request might seem to me. I must say only what the LORD says.'
24.14: Even though I'm going back to my people, I'll give you some advice. I'll tell you what these people will do to your people in the days to come."
24.15: Then Balaam delivered this message: "This is the message of Balaam, son of Beor. This is the message of the man whose eyesight is clear.
24.16: This is the message of the one who hears the words of God, receives knowledge from the Most High, has a vision from the Almighty, and falls [into a trance] with his eyes open:
24.17: I see someone who is not here now. I look at someone who is not nearby. A star will come from Jacob. A scepter will rise from Israel. He will crush the heads of the Moabites and destroy all the people of Sheth.
24.18: Edom will be conquered, and Seir, his enemy, will be conquered. So Israel will become wealthy.
24.19: He will rule from Jacob and destroy whoever is left in their cities."
24.20: Then Balaam saw the Amalekites and delivered this message: "Amalek was first among the nations, but in the end it will be destroyed."
24.21: Then he saw the Kenites and delivered this message: "You have a permanent place to live. Your nest is built in a rock.
24.22: But it is destined to be burned, you [descendants of] Cain, when Assyria takes you as prisoners of war."
24.23: He delivered this message: "Oh no! Who will live when God decides to do this?
24.24: Ships will come from the shores of Cyprus. They will conquer Assyria and Eber. But they, too, will be totally destroyed."
24.25: Then Balaam got up and went back home, and Balak also went on his way.

25.1: While Israel was staying at Shittim, the men began to have sex with Moabite women
25.2: who invited the people to the sacrifices offered to their gods. The people ate the meat from the sacrifices and worshiped these gods.
25.3: Since the Israelites joined in worshiping the god Baal of Peor, the LORD became angry with Israel.
25.4: The LORD said to Moses, "Take all the leaders of the people, and execute them in broad daylight in the LORD's presence. This will turn the LORD's anger away from Israel."
25.5: So Moses said to the judges of Israel, "Each of you must kill the men who have joined in worshiping the god Baal of Peor."
25.6: One of the Israelite men brought a Midianite woman to his brothers. He did this right in front of Moses and the whole community of Israel while they were crying at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
25.7: Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of the priest Aaron, saw this. So he left the assembly, took a spear in his hand,
25.8: and went into the tent after the Israelite man. He drove the spear through the man and into the woman's body. Because of this, the plague that the Israelites were experiencing stopped.
25.9: However, 24,000 people died from that plague.
25.10: Then the LORD said to Moses,
25.11: "Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of the priest Aaron, turned my fury away from the Israelites. Since he stood up for me, I didn't have to stand up for myself and destroy them.
25.12: So tell Phinehas that I'm making a promise of peace to him.
25.13: My promise is that he and his descendants will be priests permanently because he stood up for his God and he made peace with the LORD for the Israelites."
25.14: The name of the Israelite man who was killed with the Midianite woman was Zimri, son of Salu. (Salu was the leader of a family from Simeon.)
25.15: The name of the Midianite woman who was killed was Cozbi, daughter of Zur. (Zur was the head of a family from the Midianite tribes.)
25.17: "Treat the Midianites as your enemies, and kill them
25.18: because they treated you as enemies. They plotted to trick you in the incident that took place at Peor. They used their sister Cozbi, daughter of a Midianite leader, who was killed on the day of the plague caused by the incident at Peor."

26.1: After the plague the LORD said to Moses and Eleazar, son of the priest Aaron,
26.2: "Take a census of the whole community of Israel by households. List those who are at least 20 years old and eligible for military duty."
26.3: So Moses and the priest Eleazar spoke to the Israelites on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho. They said,
26.4: "Take a census of those at least 20 years old, as the LORD commanded Moses." These are the Israelites who came from Egypt:
26.5: [Reuben] was Israel's firstborn. The descendants of Reuben were the family of Hanoch, the family of Pallu,
26.6: the family of Hezron, and the family of Carmi.
26.7: These were the families of Reuben. The total number of men was 43,730.
26.8: Eliab was the son of Pallu,
26.9: and Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram were the sons of Eliab. (It was Dathan and Abiram, men chosen by the community, who defied Moses and Aaron's authority. They joined Korah's followers when they defied the LORD's authority.
26.10: The ground opened up and swallowed them along with Korah. They and their followers died when the fire consumed the 250 men. This was a warning.
26.11: But the descendants of Korah didn't die.)
26.12: The families descended from [Simeon] were the family of Nemuel, the family of Jamin, the family of Jakin,
26.13: the family of Zerah, and the family of Shaul.
26.14: These were the families of Simeon. The total number of men was 22,200.
26.15: The families descended from [Gad] were the family of Zephon, the family of Haggi, the family of Shuni,
26.16: the family of Ozni, the family of Eri,
26.17: the family of Arodi, and the family of Areli.
26.18: These were the families of Gad's descendants. The total number of men was 40,500.
26.19: Er and Onan were sons of Judah, but they died in Canaan.
26.20: The families descended from [Judah] were the family of Shelah, the family of Perez, and the family of Zerah.
26.21: The descendants of Perez were the family of Hezron and the family of Hamul.
26.22: These were the families of Judah. The total number of men was 76,500.
26.23: The families descended from [Issachar] were the family of Tola, the family of Puah,
26.24: the family of Jashub, and the family of Shimron.
26.25: These were the families of Issachar. The total number of men was 64,300.
26.26: The families descended from [Zebulun] were the family of Sered, the family of Elon, and the family of Jahleel.
26.27: These were the families of Zebulun. The total number of men was 60,500.
26.28: The families descended from [Joseph] [through] Manasseh and Ephraim were
26.29: (from Manasseh) the family of Machir (Machir was the father of Gilead) and the family of Gilead.
26.30: The descendants of Gilead were the family of Iezer, the family of Helek,
26.31: the family of Asriel, the family of Shechem,
26.32: the family of Shemida, and the family of Hepher.
26.33: (Zelophehad, son of Hepher, had no sons-only daughters. Their names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.)
26.34: These were the families of Manasseh. The total number of men was 52,700.
26.35: The families descended from Ephraim were the family of Shuthelah, the family of Beker, and the family of Tahan.
26.36: The descendants of Shuthelah were the family of Eran.
26.37: These were the families of Ephraim's descendants. The total number of men was 32,500. These were the families descended from Joseph.
26.38: The families descended from [Benjamin] were the family of Bela, the family of Ashbel, the family of Ahiram,
26.39: the family of Shupham, and the family of Hupham.
26.40: The descendants of Bela ( [through] Ard and Naaman) were the family of Ard and the family of Naaman.
26.41: These were the families descended from Benjamin. The total number of men was 45,600.
26.42: The family descended from [Dan] was the family of Shuham. This was the family descended from Dan.
26.43: The total number of men in all the family of Shuham was 64,400.
26.44: The families descended from [Asher] were the family of Imnah, the family of Ishvi, and the family of Beriah.
26.45: The descendants of Beriah were the family of Heber and the family of Malchiel.
26.47: These were the families of Asher's descendants. The total number of men was 53,400.
26.48: The families descended from [Naphtali] were the family of Jahzeel, the family of Guni,
26.49: the family of Jezer, and the family of Shillem.
26.50: These were the families of Naphtali. The total number of men was 45,400.
26.51: The total number of Israelite men was 601,730.
26.52: Then the LORD said to Moses,
26.53: "The land these people will possess must be divided using the list of names [from the census].
26.54: Give more land to larger tribes and less land to smaller ones. Use the totals [from the census] in giving land to each tribe.
26.55: But the land must be divided by drawing lots. The tribes will receive their land based on the names of their ancestors.
26.56: Whether the tribes are large or small, the land must be divided by drawing lots."
26.57: The families descended from [Levi] were listed as the family of Gershon, the family of Kohath, and the family of Merari.
26.58: These were the families of Levi: the Libnite family, the Hebronite family, the Mahlite family, the Mushite family, and the Korahite family. Kohath was the ancestor of Amram.
26.59: The name of Amram's wife was Jochebed, a descendant of Levi, who was born in Egypt. She gave birth to Amram's children: Aaron, Moses, and their sister Miriam.
26.60: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
26.61: But Nadab and Abihu had died because they offered unauthorized fire in the LORD's presence.
26.62: The total number of all the [Levite] males at least one month old was 23,000. They were not counted along with the other Israelites, because they were given no land of their own.
26.63: Moses and the priest Eleazar added up the total number of Israelites on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.
26.64: Among them there wasn't a single one of the Israelites Moses and the priest Aaron had counted in the Desert of Sinai.
26.65: The LORD had said, "They must all die in the desert." The only ones left were Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun).

27.1: The daughters of Zelophehad, son of Hepher, grandson of Gilead, descendant of Machir, whose father was Manasseh, belonged to the families of Manasseh, son of Joseph. Their names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They came
27.2: to Moses and stood in front of him, the priest Eleazar, the leaders, and the whole community at the entrance to the tent of meeting. They said,
27.3: "Our father died in the desert. He was not a part of Korah's followers who joined forces against the LORD. He died for his own sin and left no sons.
27.4: Why should our father's name be allowed to die out in his family because he had no son? Give us property among our father's relatives."
27.5: So Moses brought their case to the LORD,
27.6: and the LORD said to him,
27.7: "Zelophehad's daughters are right. You must give them property of their own among their father's relatives. Turn their father's property over to them.
27.8: "Tell the Israelites: If a man dies and leaves no sons, turn his property over to his daughters.
27.9: If he has no daughters, give his property to his brothers.
27.10: If he has no brothers, give his property to his uncles on his father's side of the family.
27.11: If he has no uncles, give his property to the nearest relative in his family, and that relative will take possession of it. This will be a rule for the Israelites, as the LORD commanded Moses."
27.12: The LORD said to Moses, "Go up into the Abarim Mountains, and take a look at the land I will give the Israelites.
27.13: After you see it, you, too, will join your ancestors [in death], as your brother Aaron did.
27.14: You both rebelled against my command in the Desert of Zin. You didn't show the people how holy I am when they were complaining at the oasis." (This was the oasis of Meribah at Kadesh in the Desert of Zin.)
27.16: "LORD, you are the God who gives the breath of life to everyone. Please appoint someone over the community
27.17: who will lead them in and out [of battle] so that the LORD's community will not be like sheep without a shepherd."
27.18: So the LORD said to Moses, "Take Joshua, son of Nun, a man who has the Spirit, and place your hand on him.
27.19: Make him stand in front of the priest Eleazar and the whole community, and give him his instructions in their presence.
27.20: Give him some of your authority so that the whole community of Israel will obey him.
27.21: He will stand in front of the priest Eleazar, who will use the Urim to make decisions in the LORD's presence. At his command Joshua and the whole community of Israel will go into battle. And at his command they will return."
27.22: Moses did as the LORD commanded him. He took Joshua and made him stand in front of the priest Eleazar and the whole community.
27.23: Moses placed his hands on Joshua and gave him his instructions as the LORD had told him.

28.2: "Give this command to the Israelites: Be sure to bring me my offerings at the right times. They are my food. They are offerings by fire, a soothing aroma.
28.3: These are the offerings by fire that you must bring to the LORD. Every day you must bring as a daily burnt offering two one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
28.4: Offer one in the morning and the other at dusk.
28.5: [With each of them] also bring a grain offering of eight cups of flour mixed with one quart of virgin olive oil.
28.6: This is the daily burnt offering which was established on Mount Sinai. This offering is a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD.
28.7: Also bring a wine offering of one quart of wine for each lamb. Pour it out to the LORD in a holy place.
28.8: Offer the other lamb at dusk along with the same grain offering and wine offering as you brought in the morning. This is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to the LORD.
28.9: "On the day of worship offer two one-year-old lambs that have no defects, a grain offering of 16 cups of flour mixed with olive oil, and the wine offering that goes with it.
28.10: This burnt offering is for every day of worship in addition to the daily burnt offerings and the wine offerings that go with them.
28.11: "On the first of every month bring the LORD a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
28.12: With each bull there will be a grain offering of 24 cups of flour mixed with olive oil, with each ram a grain offering of 16 cups of flour mixed with olive oil,
28.13: and with each one-year-old lamb a grain offering of 8 cups of flour mixed with olive oil. This is a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD.
28.14: The wine offering that goes with each bull will be 2 quarts of wine, with each ram 1 1/2 quarts of wine, and with each lamb 1 quart of wine. This will be the monthly burnt offering for every month of the year.
28.15: In addition to the daily burnt offering with its wine offering, one male goat must be offered to the LORD as an offering for sin.
28.16: "The fourteenth day of the first month is the LORD's Passover.
28.17: The fifteenth of this same month is a pilgrimage festival. For seven days you must eat only unleavened bread.
28.18: On the first day there will be a holy assembly. Don't do any regular work.
28.19: Instead, bring the LORD an offering by fire, a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
28.20: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
28.21: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
28.22: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin to make peace with the LORD.
28.23: Offer these in addition to the morning burnt offering.
28.24: Bring all these offerings on each of the seven days. They are food. They are offerings by fire, a soothing aroma to the LORD. They will be offered in addition to the daily burnt offering and the wine offering that goes with it.
28.25: On the seventh day you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work.
28.26: "During the Festival of Weeks, you must have a holy assembly. On that day you must not do any regular work. Bring the LORD your new grain offering, the first produce harvested from your fields.
28.27: Bring a burnt offering as a soothing aroma to the LORD-two young bulls, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs.
28.28: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
28.29: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
28.30: Also bring one male goat to make peace with the LORD.
28.31: Offer these animals that have no defects along with their wine offerings, in addition to the daily burnt offerings and their grain offerings."

29.1: [The LORD continued,] "On the first day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work. It is a day for [the trumpets to sound] a fanfare.
29.2: As a burnt offering, a soothing aroma to the LORD, bring one young bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.3: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
29.4: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
29.5: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin to make peace with the LORD.
29.6: Offer these in addition to the monthly burnt offering with its grain offering, and the daily burnt offerings with their proper grain offerings and wine offerings. They are a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD.
29.7: "On the tenth day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must humble yourselves. You must not do any work.
29.8: As a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, bring one young bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
29.9: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each bull, 16 cups for each ram,
29.10: and 8 cups for each of the seven lambs.
29.11: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin (in addition to the [other] offering for sin to make peace with the LORD) and the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.12: "On the fifteenth day of the seventh month you must have a holy assembly. You must not do any regular work. Instead, celebrate a festival to the LORD for seven days.
29.13: As a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to the LORD, bring 13 young bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs, all of them without defects.
29.14: Along with them bring grain offerings of flour mixed with olive oil. Bring 24 cups for each of the 13 bulls, 16 cups for each of the 2 rams,
29.15: and 8 cups for each of the 14 one-year-old lambs.
29.16: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.17: "On the second day bring 12 young bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.18: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.19: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.20: "On the third day bring 11 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.21: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.22: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.23: "On the fourth day bring 10 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.24: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.25: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.26: "On the fifth day bring 9 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.27: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.28: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.29: "On the sixth day bring 8 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.30: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.31: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.32: "On the seventh day bring 7 bulls, 2 rams, and 14 one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.33: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for each of the bulls, rams, and lambs.
29.34: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.35: "On the eighth day you must hold a religious assembly. You must not do any daily work.
29.36: As a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to the LORD, bring one bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects.
29.37: Along with them bring the proper amount of grain offerings and wine offerings for the bull, the ram, and the lambs.
29.38: Also bring one male goat as an offering for sin in addition to the daily burnt offerings with their grain offerings and wine offerings.
29.39: "These are the offerings you must bring to the LORD at your festivals. They are the offerings you must bring in addition to the offerings for anything you vowed to give to the LORD, your freewill offerings, your burnt offerings, your grain offerings, your wine offerings, and your fellowship offerings."
29.40: Moses told the Israelites everything the LORD had commanded him.

30.1: Moses said to the heads of the tribes of Israel, "This is what the LORD has commanded [about vows]:
30.2: If a man makes a vow to the LORD that he will do something or swears an oath that he won't do something, he must not break his word. He must do everything he said he would do.
30.3: "A young girl, who still lives in her father's house, might make a vow to the LORD that she will do something or swear an oath that she won't do something.
30.4: If her father says nothing to her when he hears about it, her vow or oath must be kept.
30.5: But if her father objects when he hears about it, her vow or oath doesn't have to be kept. The LORD will free her [from this vow or oath] because her father objected.
30.6: "An unmarried woman might make a vow that she will do something or carelessly promise that she won't do something. When she marries,
30.7: her husband may hear about it but say nothing to her. Then her vow or oath must be kept.
30.8: But if her husband objects when he hears about it, he can cancel the vow or promise she made. The LORD will free her [from this vow or promise].
30.9: "But a widow or a divorced woman must keep her vow or her promise.
30.10: "A married woman might make a vow that she will do something or swear an oath that she won't do something.
30.11: Her husband may hear about it but may say nothing and not object. Then her vow or oath must be kept.
30.12: But if her husband cancels it when he hears about it, nothing she said in her vow or oath has to be kept. Her husband has canceled it, and the LORD will free her [from this vow or oath].
30.13: "A husband decides whether or not his wife has to keep any vow to do something or any oath to do without something.
30.14: If he says nothing to her about it day after day, this means he's decided that she must keep her vow or oath. She must keep it because he said nothing to her when he heard about it.
30.15: But if he cancels it later, he will suffer the consequences."
30.16: These are the laws the LORD gave Moses for husbands and wives, and for fathers with young daughters still living at home.

31.2: "Get even with the Midianites for what they did to the Israelites. After that you will join your ancestors [in death]."
31.3: Moses said to the people, "Some of your men must get ready to go to war against the Midianites. The LORD will use them to get even with Midian.
31.4: Send 1,000 men from each of the tribes of Israel."
31.5: So 1,000 men from each tribe were supplied from the divisions of Israel-12,000 men ready for war.
31.6: Then Moses sent them off to war, 1,000 men from each tribe along with Phinehas, son of the priest Eleazar. Phinehas took with him the holy articles and the trumpets for the fanfare.
31.7: They went to war against Midian, as the LORD commanded Moses, and killed every man.
31.8: Among those killed were the five kings of Midian-Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. They also killed Balaam, son of Beor, in battle.
31.9: The Israelites took the Midianite women and children as prisoners of war. They also took all their animals, their livestock, and their valuables as loot.
31.10: They burned all the cities where the Midianites lived and all their settlements.
31.11: Then they took everything as loot, including all the people and animals,
31.12: and brought the prisoners of war, the loot, and everything to Moses, the priest Eleazar, and the community of Israel at the camp on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.
31.13: Moses, the priest Eleazar, and all the leaders of the community went outside the camp to meet them.
31.14: Moses was angry with the officers of the army, the commanders of the companies and battalions, who were returning from battle.
31.15: "Why did you let all the women live?" he asked them.
31.16: "Remember, they were the ones who followed Balaam's advice and caused the Israelites to be unfaithful to the LORD in the incident that took place at Peor. The LORD's community experienced a plague at that time.
31.17: So kill all the Midianite boys and every Midianite woman who has gone to bed with a man.
31.18: But save for yourselves every girl who has never gone to bed with a man.
31.19: "Everyone who killed a person or touched a dead body must stay outside the camp seven days. You and your prisoners of war must use the ritual water on the third and seventh days in order to take away your sin.
31.20: Do the same for all the clothes and everything made of leather, goats' hair, or wood."
31.21: Then the priest Eleazar said to the soldiers who had gone into battle, "This is what the LORD's teachings told Moses to do:
31.22: Any gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, or lead-
31.23: anything that won't burn-must be put through fire in order to make it clean. Then it must also be put through the ritual water in order to take away its sin. Whatever might burn must [only] be put through the ritual water.
31.24: On the seventh day wash your clothes, and you will be clean. Then you may come into the camp."
31.26: "You, the priest Eleazar, and the heads of the families of the community need to count all the loot, including the people and animals you captured.
31.27: Divide the loot between the soldiers who served in the war and the rest of the community.
31.28: Collect a tax for the LORD. From the soldiers who served in the war collect one out of every 500 things. This includes people, cattle, donkeys, sheep, and goats.
31.29: Collect all these things from the soldiers' half of the loot, and give them to the priest Eleazar as a contribution to the LORD.
31.30: From the Israelites' half of the loot, collect one out of every 50 things. This includes people, cattle, donkeys, sheep, goats, and every other kind of animal. Give them to the Levites who are in charge of the work done at the LORD's tent."
31.31: Moses and the priest Eleazar did as the LORD commanded Moses.
31.32: This is the loot that was left from everything that the troops took: 675,000 sheep and goats,
31.35: 32,000 women who had never gone to bed with a man.
31.36: Half of it went to the soldiers who served in the war. Of the 337,500 sheep and goats they received,
31.37: 675 went to the LORD as taxes.
31.38: Of the 36,000 cattle they received, 72 went to the LORD as taxes.
31.39: Of the 30,500 donkeys they received, 61 went to the LORD as taxes.
31.40: Of the 16,000 people they received, 32 went to the LORD as taxes.
31.41: Moses gave the LORD's taxes to the priest Eleazar, as the LORD had commanded him.
31.42: Moses took the Israelites' half of the loot from the soldiers.
31.43: The community received 337,500 sheep and goats,
31.47: From the Israelites' half Moses collected one out of every 50 things, including people and animals, as the LORD commanded him. Then he gave all this to the Levites who were in charge of the work done at the LORD's tent.
31.48: Then the officers from the military divisions, the commanders of the companies and battalions of men, came to Moses.
31.49: They said to him, "Sir, we have counted all the soldiers under our command, and not one of them is missing.
31.50: So we have brought as gifts to the LORD the gold jewelry that each of us found-arm bands, bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and pendants. We offer them to make peace with the LORD."
31.51: Moses and the priest Eleazar took all the hand-crafted gold articles from them.
31.52: All the gold contributed to the LORD by the commanders weighed about 420 pounds.
31.53: Each soldier kept his own loot.
31.54: Moses and the priest Eleazar took the gold from the commanders and brought it into the LORD's presence at the tent of meeting as a reminder to the Israelites.

32.1: The tribes of Reuben and Gad had a large number of livestock. They saw that the regions of Jazer and Gilead were a good place for livestock.
32.2: So they came to Moses, the priest Eleazar, and the leaders of the community, and said to them,
32.3: "Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon,
32.4: the land that the LORD won for the community of Israel, is a good place for livestock. Gentlemen, we have livestock.
32.5: Please give us this land as our property. Don't make us cross the Jordan River."
32.6: Moses asked the tribes of Gad and Reuben, "Are you going to stay here while the rest of the Israelites go to war?
32.7: That might discourage them from entering the land the LORD has given them.
32.8: That's what your ancestors did when I sent them from Kadesh Barnea to take a look at the land.
32.9: They went as far as the Eshcol Valley and saw the land. But then they discouraged the rest of the Israelites from entering the land that the LORD had given them.
32.10: That day the LORD became angry and swore this oath,
32.11: 'None of the people 20 years old or older, who came from Egypt, will see the land I promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob with an oath. This is because they didn't wholeheartedly follow me.'
32.12: Only Caleb (son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite) and Joshua (son of Nun) will get to see the land. This is because they wholeheartedly followed the LORD.
32.13: Since the LORD was angry with the Israelites, he made them wander in the desert for 40 years until the whole generation of those who had done evil in the LORD's presence was gone.
32.14: "You're just like your parents! You're a bunch of sinners trying to make the LORD angry with Israel again.
32.15: If you turn away from him, he will abandon all these people in the desert. You would be responsible for their destruction."
32.16: Then the tribes of Gad and Reuben came up to Moses and said, "Allow us to build stone fences for our livestock and cities for our families here.
32.17: Then we'll be ready [to march] in battle formation?to march[ ahead quickly."> ahead of the other Israelites until we have brought them to their land. Meanwhile our families will live in walled cities, safe from the other people who live here.]
32.18: We will not return to our homes until every Israelite has received his own land.
32.19: We won't take possession of any land on the other side of the Jordan River, to the west and beyond. We already have our land here, east of the Jordan."
32.20: Moses answered, "Do what you have said. In the LORD's presence have all your armed men get ready for battle.
32.21: Have them cross the Jordan, and fight until the LORD forces out his enemies
32.22: and the land is conquered. Then you may come back. You will have fulfilled your military duty to the LORD and Israel. This land will be your own property in the LORD's presence.
32.23: "If you don't do all these things, you will be sinning against the LORD. You can be sure that you will be punished for your sin.
32.24: Build cities for your families and stone fences for your flocks, but do what you have promised."
32.25: Then the tribes of Gad and Reuben said to Moses, "Sir, we will do as you command.
32.26: Our children, our wives, our livestock, and all our other animals will stay here in the cities of Gilead.
32.27: But in the LORD's presence we will all get ready for battle and go with you, as you have said."
32.28: So Moses gave orders about them to the priest Eleazar, Joshua (son of Nun), and the family heads of the tribes of Israel.
32.29: Moses told them, "If the tribes of Gad and Reuben get ready for battle in the LORD's presence and cross the Jordan River with you and you conquer the land, give them Gilead as their own property.
32.30: If they don't get ready for battle and go with you, the land they will take possession of must be in Canaan with yours."
32.31: The tribes of Gad and Reuben answered, "Sir, we will do as the LORD has said.
32.32: We will enter Canaan as armed troops in the LORD's presence, but the land we will take possession of is here, east of the Jordan."
32.33: So Moses gave the tribes of Gad, Reuben, and half of the tribe of Manasseh, son of Joseph, the kingdoms of King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan-the whole land with its cities and its surrounding territory.
32.34: The tribe of Gad rebuilt the cities of Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
32.36: Beth Nimrah, and Beth Haran as walled cities. They also built stone fences for their flocks.
32.37: The tribe of Reuben rebuilt the cities of Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
32.38: Nebo, Baal Meon (whose names were changed), and Sibmah. These are the names they gave the cities they rebuilt.
32.39: The descendants of Machir, son of Manasseh, went to Gilead, captured it, and forced out the Amorites who were there.
32.40: So Moses gave Gilead to the people of Machir (the descendants of Manasseh), and they lived there.
32.41: Then Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, captured the settlements in Gilead. He called them Havvoth Jair [Settlements of Jair].
32.42: Nobah captured Kenath and its villages. He named it Nobah after himself.

33.1: This is a list of all the places where the Israelites set up camp after they left Egypt in organized groups under the leadership of Moses and Aaron.
33.2: At the LORD's command Moses wrote down the places where they went as they traveled. This is the list:
33.3: They moved from Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, the day after the Passover. The Israelites boldly left in full view of all the Egyptians.
33.4: The Egyptians were burying all their firstborn sons, whom the LORD had killed in a mighty act of judgment on their gods.
33.5: The Israelites moved from Rameses and set up camp at Succoth.
33.6: They moved from Succoth and set up camp at Etham, on the edge of the desert.
33.7: They moved from Etham and turned back to Pi Hahiroth, east of Baal Zephon, and set up camp near Migdol.
33.8: They moved from Pi Hahiroth and went through the middle of the sea into the desert. After they traveled for three days in the Desert of Etham, they set up camp at Marah.
33.9: They moved from Marah and came to Elim. Elim had 12 springs and 70 palm trees, so they set up camp there.
33.10: They moved from Elim and set up camp by the Red Sea.
33.11: They moved from the Red Sea and set up camp in the Desert of Sin.
33.12: They moved from the Desert of Sin and set up camp at Dophkah.
33.13: They moved from Dophkah and set up camp at Alush.
33.14: They moved from Alush and set up camp at Rephidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
33.15: They moved from Rephidim and set up camp in the Desert of Sinai.
33.16: They moved from the Desert of Sinai and set up camp at Kibroth Hattaavah.
33.17: They moved from Kibroth Hattaavah and set up camp at Hazeroth.
33.18: They moved from Hazeroth and set up camp at Rithmah.
33.19: They moved from Rithmah and set up camp at Rimmon Perez.
33.20: They moved from Rimmon Perez and set up camp at Libnah.
33.21: They moved from Libnah and set up camp at Rissah.
33.22: They moved from Rissah and set up camp at Kehelathah.
33.23: They moved from Kehelathah and set up camp at Mount Shepher.
33.24: They moved from Mount Shepher and set up camp at Haradah.
33.25: They moved from Haradah and set up camp at Makheloth.
33.26: They moved from Makheloth and set up camp at Tahath.
33.27: They moved from Tahath and set up camp at Terah.
33.28: They moved from Terah and set up camp at Mithcah.
33.29: They moved from Mithcah and set up camp at Hashmonah.
33.30: They moved from Hashmonah and set up camp at Moseroth.
33.31: They moved from Moseroth and set up camp at Bene Jaakan.
33.32: They moved from Bene Jaakan and set up camp at Hor Haggidgad.
33.33: They moved from Hor Haggidgad and set up camp at Jotbathah.
33.34: They moved from Jotbathah and set up camp at Abronah.
33.35: They moved from Abronah and set up camp at Ezion Geber.
33.36: They moved from Ezion Geber and set up camp at Kadesh in the Desert of Zin.
33.37: They moved from Kadesh and set up camp at Mount Hor on the border of Edom.
33.38: At the LORD's command the priest Aaron went up on Mount Hor. He died there on the first day of the fifth month in the fortieth year after the Israelites had left Egypt.
33.39: Aaron was 123 years old when he died on Mount Hor.
33.40: (The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, which was in Canaan, heard that the Israelites were coming.)
33.41: They moved from Mount Hor and set up camp at Zalmonah.
33.42: They moved from Zalmonah and set up camp at Punon.
33.43: They moved from Punon and set up camp at Oboth.
33.44: They moved from Oboth and set up camp at Iye Abarim on the border of Moab.
33.45: They moved from Iyim and set up camp at Dibon Gad.
33.46: They moved from Dibon Gad and set up camp at Almon Diblathaim.
33.47: They moved from Almon Diblathaim and set up camp in the Abarim Mountains east of Nebo.
33.48: They moved from the Abarim Mountains and set up camp on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.
33.49: They set up camp on the plains of Moab along the Jordan. Their camp extended from Beth Jeshimoth to Abel Shittim.
33.50: The LORD said to Moses on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho,
33.51: "Tell the Israelites, 'You will be crossing the Jordan River and entering Canaan.
33.52: As you advance, force out all the people who live there. Get rid of all their stone and metal idols, and destroy all their places of worship.
33.53: Take possession of the land and live there, because I will give it to you for your own.
33.54: Divide the land among your families by drawing lots. Give more land to larger families and less land to smaller ones. The land must be given to each family by drawing lots. Divide it among your ancestors' tribes.
33.55: " 'But if you do not force out those who live in the land, they will be like splinters in your eyes and thorns in your sides. They will constantly fight with you over the land you live in.
33.56: Then I will do to you what I planned to do to them.'"

34.2: "Give the Israelites these instructions. When you enter Canaan, the land that will be given to you as your inheritance has these borders:
34.3: "The southern side includes part of the Desert of Zin along the border of Edom. In the east the southern border starts from the end of the Dead Sea
34.4: and turns south of the Akrabbim Pass. It then goes past Zin and ends at Kadesh Barnea. From there it goes to Hazar Addar and on to Azmon.
34.5: From Azmon it turns toward the River of Egypt so that the border ends at the Mediterranean Sea.
34.6: "The western border is the coastline of the Mediterranean Sea.
34.7: "The northern border extends from the Mediterranean Sea to Mount Hor,
34.8: and from Mount Hor to the border of Hamath so that it ends at Zedad.
34.9: From there the border goes to Ziphron and ends at Hazar Enan.
34.10: "The eastern border extends from Hazar Enan to Shepham.
34.11: From Shepham the border goes down to Riblah, east of Ain, and continues along the eastern slope of the Sea of Galilee.
34.12: Then the border goes along the Jordan River so that it ends at the Dead Sea. "This will be your land and the borders around it."
34.13: Moses commanded the Israelites, "This is the land you will divide by drawing lots. The LORD has commanded that this land will be given to the nine-and-a-half tribes.
34.14: The households from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh have already received their land.
34.15: Those two-and-a-half tribes received land east of the Jordan River across from Jericho."
34.17: "These are the names of the men who will divide the land for you: the priest Eleazar and Joshua, son of Nun.
34.18: You must also take one leader from each tribe to divide the land.
34.19: These are their names: Caleb, son of Jephunneh, from the tribe of Judah;
34.20: Shemuel, son of Ammihud, from the tribe of Simeon;
34.21: Elidad, son of Kislon, from the tribe of Benjamin;
34.22: Bukki, son of Jogli, the leader of the tribe of Dan;
34.23: Hanniel, son of Ephod, the leader of the tribe of Manasseh;
34.24: Kemuel, son of Shiphtan, the leader of the tribe of Ephraim; (Manasseh and Ephraim are Joseph's descendants.)
34.25: Elizaphan, son of Parnach, the leader of the tribe of Zebulun;
34.26: Paltiel, son of Azzan, the leader of the tribe of Issachar;
34.27: Ahihud, son of Shelomi, the leader of the tribe of Asher;
34.28: Pedahel, son of Ammihud, the leader of the tribe of Naphtali."
34.29: These are the men the LORD commanded to divide Canaan for the Israelites.

35.1: The LORD spoke to Moses on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho. He said,
35.2: "Tell the Israelites to give the Levites some cities from their own property. They must also give the Levites the pastureland around those cities.
35.3: Then the Levites will have cities to live in and pastureland for their cattle, the flocks they own, and any other animals they have.
35.4: "The land around the cities that you give the Levites will extend 1,500 feet from the city wall.
35.5: Outside the city measure off 3,000 feet on the east side, 3,000 feet on the south side, 3,000 feet on the west side, and 3,000 feet on the north side, with the city in the center. This will be their pastureland around the city.
35.6: "Six of the cities you give the Levites will be cities of refuge. You must allow murderers to escape to these cities. In addition, you must also give the Levites 42 other cities.
35.7: So you will give a total of 48 cities with pastureland to the Levites.
35.8: The cities you give the Levites from the property of the other Israelites must be given based on the amount of land each tribe owns. Take more cities from larger tribes and fewer from smaller tribes."
35.10: "Tell the Israelites: When you cross the Jordan River and enter Canaan,
35.11: select certain cities to be places of refuge. Anyone who unintentionally kills another person may run to them.
35.12: These cities will be places of refuge from any relative who can avenge the death. So anyone accused of murder will not have to die until he has had a trial in front of the community.
35.13: There will be six cities you select as places of refuge,
35.14: three on the east side of the Jordan River and three in Canaan.
35.15: These six cities will be places of refuge for Israelites, foreigners, and strangers among you. Anyone who unintentionally kills another person may flee to these cities.
35.16: "But if any of you uses an iron weapon to kill another person, you are a murderer. Murderers must be put to death.
35.17: If any of you picks up a stone as a weapon and uses it to kill another person, you are a murderer. Murderers must be put to death.
35.18: Or if any of you picks up a piece of wood as a weapon and uses it to kill another person, you are a murderer. Murderers must be put to death.
35.19: The relative who can avenge the death must make sure a murderer is put to death. When he catches up with the murderer, he must kill him.
35.20: If any of you kills someone you hate by shoving him or by deliberately throwing something at him,
35.21: or if you beat your enemy to death with your bare hands, you must be put to death. You are a murderer. The relative who can avenge the death must kill you when he catches up with you, because you are a murderer.
35.22: "But suppose you accidentally kill someone who wasn't your enemy. Maybe you shoved him or threw something at him but didn't mean to kill him.
35.23: Or suppose you drop a big stone, and someone is killed. However, you didn't know the person was there, he wasn't your enemy, and you weren't trying to harm him.
35.24: Then the community must use these rules in order to decide if you [are innocent] or if the dead person's relative can avenge the death.
35.25: [If you are innocent,] the community must protect you from that relative. They must take you back to the city of refuge you fled to. You must live there until the death of the chief priest who was anointed with the holy oil.
35.26: "But don't go outside the city of refuge you fled to.
35.27: If the relative who can avenge the death finds you outside the city of refuge and kills you, the relative is not guilty of murder.
35.28: Accused murderers must stay in their city of refuge until the death of the chief priest. They may go back to their own property only after his death.
35.29: "These will be the rules for future generations wherever you live.
35.30: "Whoever kills another person will be put to death as a murderer only on the testimony of more than one witness. No one can be put to death on the testimony of only one witness.
35.31: "Never accept a cash payment in exchange for the life of a convicted murderer who has been given the death penalty. Murderers must be put to death.
35.32: "An accused murderer who has fled to a city of refuge must never go back and live on his own land before the death of the chief priest. Don't accept a cash payment to allow him to do this.
35.33: "You must not pollute the land where you live. Murder is what pollutes the land. The land where a murder was committed can never make peace with the LORD except through the death of the murderer.
35.34: Never make the land where you and I live unclean. I, the LORD, live among the Israelites."

36.1: The heads of the households whose families were descended from Gilead, son of Machir and grandson of Manasseh (families of Joseph's descendants), came and spoke to Moses and the leaders of the other Israelite households.
36.2: They said, "Sir, the LORD commanded you to give the Israelites their land by drawing lots. The LORD also commanded you to give the land of our relative Zelophehad to his daughters.
36.3: Suppose they marry men from the other tribes of Israel. Their land will be taken away from that of our ancestors and added to the land of the tribe they marry into. Then we will have lost part of our land.
36.4: When the Israelites' jubilee year comes, their land will be added to that of the tribe they married into. Then part of the land of our ancestor's tribe will be gone."
36.5: So Moses gave the Israelites a command from the LORD. "The tribe of Joseph's descendants is right.
36.6: This is what the LORD commands for Zelophehad's daughters: They may marry anyone they want to, but only within a family of their ancestor's tribe.
36.7: In this way no land of the Israelites will pass from one tribe to another. Every Israelite must keep the tribal land inherited from his ancestors.
36.8: A woman who inherits land in any of the tribes of Israel may marry a man from any family in her ancestor's tribe. In this way every Israelite keeps the land inherited from his ancestors.
36.9: No land may pass from one tribe to another. Each Israelite tribe must keep the land it inherits."
36.10: Zelophehad's daughters did as the LORD commanded Moses.
36.11: Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah married their cousins on their father's side of the family.
36.12: They married within the families of the descendants of Manasseh, son of Joseph. So their land stayed in the tribe of their father's family.
36.13: These are the commands and rules the LORD gave the Israelites through Moses on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River across from Jericho.

1.1: This is the speech Moses gave in the desert east of the Jordan River, on the plains, near Suph, between Paran and Tophel, and near Laban, Hazeroth, and Di Zahab. He spoke to all the Israelites.
1.2: (It takes 11 days to go from Mount Horeb to Kadesh Barnea by way of Mount Seir.)
1.3: On the first day of the eleventh month in the fortieth year [after they had left Egypt], Moses told the Israelites everything the LORD had commanded him to tell them.
1.4: This was after he had defeated King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon, and King Og of Bashan, who ruled in Ashtaroth and in Edrei.
1.5: The Israelites were east of the Jordan River in Moab when Moses began to review God's teachings. This is what he said:
1.6: At Mount Horeb the LORD our God said to us, "You have stayed at this mountain long enough.
1.7: Break camp, and get ready! Go to the mountain region of the Amorites, and go to everyone living on the plains, in the mountains, in the foothills, in the Negev, on the whole Mediterranean coast (the land of the Canaanites), and into Lebanon as far as the Euphrates River.
1.8: I'm giving you this land. Enter, and take possession of the land the LORD swore to give to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and to you, their descendants."
1.9: At that time I said to you, "I'm not able to take care of you by myself.
1.10: The LORD your God has made your population increase so that you are now as numerous as the stars in the sky.
1.11: May the LORD God of your ancestors make you a thousand times more numerous, and may he bless you as he has promised.
1.12: How can I take care of your problems, your troubles, and your disagreements all by myself?
1.13: From each of your tribes, choose some men who are wise, intelligent, and experienced, and I'll appoint them to be your leaders."
1.14: You agreed that this was a good idea.
1.15: So I took the heads of your tribes who were wise and experienced men and made them officers for each of your tribes. I put them in charge of groups of 1,000, or 100, or 50, or 10 people.
1.16: Also at that time I gave these instructions to your judges: "Hear the cases that your people bring. Judge each case fairly, no matter whether it is [a dispute] between two Israelites or [a dispute] between an Israelite and a non-Israelite.
1.17: Be impartial in your decisions. Listen to the least important people the same way you listen to the most important people. Never be afraid of anyone, since your decisions come from God. You may bring me any case that's too hard for you, and I will hear it."
1.18: So I told you how to handle these situations.
1.19: So we left Mount Horeb, as the LORD our God had commanded. We traveled through all that vast and dangerous desert you saw on the way to the mountain region of the Amorites. At last we came to Kadesh Barnea.
1.20: Then I said to you, "We have come to the mountain region of the Amorites, which the LORD our God is giving us.
1.21: The LORD your God is giving you this land. Go ahead! Take possession of it, as the LORD God of your ancestors told you. Don't be afraid or terrified."
1.22: All of you came to me and said, "Let's send men ahead of us to gather information about the land for us. Have them report to us about the route we should take and the cities we'll come to."
1.23: It seemed like a good idea to me. So I chose 12 of your men, one from each tribe.
1.24: They left and went into the mountains. When they came to the Eshcol Valley, they explored it.
1.25: They took some of the region's fruit with them and brought it back to us. They reported, "The land that the LORD our God is giving us is good."
1.26: But you rebelled against the command of the LORD your God and refused to go.
1.27: You complained in your tents and said, "The LORD hates us! That's why he brought us out of Egypt. He wanted to hand us over to the Amorites so that they could destroy us!
1.28: Where are we going anyway? Our own men have discouraged us by saying, 'The people there are taller and stronger than we are. The cities are big with sky-high walls! We even saw the people of Anak there.'"
1.29: Then I said to you, "Don't tremble. Don't be afraid of them.
1.30: The LORD your God, who is going ahead of you, will fight for you as you saw him fight for you in Egypt
1.31: and in the desert." There you saw how the LORD your God carried you, as parents carry their children. He carried you wherever you went until you came to this place.
1.32: In spite of this, you didn't trust the LORD your God,
1.33: who went ahead of you to find places for you to camp. He appeared in a column of fire at night and in a column of smoke during the day to show you which route to take.
1.34: When the LORD heard what you said, he was angry and took this oath:
1.35: "Not one of these evil people will ever see the good land that I swore to give to your ancestors,
1.36: except Caleb, son of Jephunneh. He will see it, and I will give the land that he set his feet on to him and his descendants, because he wholeheartedly followed the LORD."
1.37: The LORD became angry with me because of you. He said, "You won't go there either.
1.38: But your assistant Joshua, son of Nun, will go there. Encourage him, because he will help Israel take possession of the land.
1.39: Although you thought the little children would be captured in war, your children, who are still too young to know the difference between good and evil, will enter that land. I will give it to them, and they will take possession of it.
1.40: Turn around, go back into the desert, and follow the road that goes to the Red Sea."
1.41: You responded, "We have sinned against the LORD. We'll go and fight, as the LORD our God commanded us to do." Each of you armed yourself for war, thinking you could easily invade the mountain region.
1.42: But the LORD said to me, "Tell them, 'Don't go and fight, because I won't be with you. You will be defeated by your enemies.'"
1.43: I told you, but you wouldn't listen. You defied the LORD's command and invaded the mountain region.
1.44: The Amorites who lived there came out and attacked you and chased you like a swarm of bees. They defeated you, chasing you from Seir all the way to Hormah.
1.45: When you came back, you cried to the LORD, but the LORD didn't listen to you or hear you.
1.46: That's why you stayed in Kadesh as long as you did.

2.1: We went back into the desert, following the road that goes to the Red Sea as the LORD had told me. For a long time we traveled around the region of Mount Seir.
2.3: "You've traveled around this region long enough. Now go north.
2.4: Give the people these instructions: 'You're going to pass through the territory of your relatives, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. They'll be afraid of you, but be very careful.
2.5: Don't start a fight with them, because I'm not giving you any of their land-not even enough to stand on. I've given Esau's descendants the region of Mount Seir as their property.
2.6: You must pay them in silver for the food you eat and the water you drink.'"
2.7: The LORD your God has blessed you in everything you have done. He has watched over you as you traveled through this vast desert. For 40 years now the LORD your God has been with you, and you haven't needed a thing.
2.8: So we passed by our relatives, the descendants of Esau, who lived in Seir. We turned off the road that goes through the plains to Elath and Ezion Geber and took the road that goes through the desert of Moab.
2.9: The LORD said to me, "Don't bother the people of Moab or start a war with them. I'm not giving you any of Ar as your property. I have given it to the descendants of Lot."
2.10: The Emites used to live there. These people were as strong, as numerous, and as tall as the people of Anak.
2.11: They were thought to be Rephaim, like the people of Anak, but the Moabites called them Emites.
2.12: The Horites used to live in Seir, but the descendants of Esau claimed their land, wiped them out, and took their place, as Israel did in the land that the LORD gave them.
2.13: Then the LORD said, "Now cross the Zered River." So we crossed the Zered River.
2.14: Thirty-eight years passed from the time we left Kadesh Barnea until we crossed the Zered River. During that time all our soldiers from that generation died, as the LORD had sworn they would.
2.15: In fact, it was the LORD himself who got rid of all of them until none were left in the camp.
2.16: When the last of these soldiers had died,
2.18: "Today you are going to pass by the border of Moab at Ar.
2.19: When you come near the Ammonites, don't bother them or start a fight with them. I'm not giving you any of the land that I have already given to the descendants of Lot as their property."
2.20: This land was thought of as the land of the Rephaim who used to live there, but the Ammonites called them Zamzummim.
2.21: These people were as strong, as numerous, and as tall as the people of Anak. But the LORD wiped them out before the Ammonites came so that the Ammonites claimed their land and took their place.
2.22: The LORD did the same thing for the descendants of Esau, who lived in Seir. Before the descendants of Esau came, he wiped out the Horites so that Esau's descendants claimed their land and took their place. Esau's descendants are still there today.
2.23: The same thing happened to the Avvites who lived in villages as far away as Gaza. The Caphtorites, who came from Crete, wiped them out and took their place.
2.24: [The LORD continued,] "Now break camp. Cross the Arnon Valley. I'm going to hand King Sihon of Heshbon, the Amorite, over to you. Fight him, and take possession of his country.
2.25: Today I will start to make all the people under heaven terrified of you. When they hear about you, they will tremble and shake because of you."
2.26: From the desert of Kedemoth, I sent messengers to King Sihon of Heshbon with the following offer of peace:
2.27: "If you allow us to travel through your country, we'll go straight through and won't ever leave the road.
2.28: We'll pay you in silver for the food we eat and the water we drink. Please let us go through,
2.29: as the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir, and the Moabites, who live in Ar, did for us. We'll keep going until we cross the Jordan River into the land the LORD our God is giving us."
2.30: But King Sihon of Heshbon wouldn't allow us to pass through. The LORD your God made him stubborn and overconfident in order to hand him over to you, as he has now done.
2.31: The LORD said to me, "I have begun to give you Sihon and his country. Go ahead! Take possession of his land."
2.32: Sihon and all his troops came out to meet us in battle at Jahaz.
2.33: The LORD our God gave Sihon to us, and we defeated him, his sons, and all his troops.
2.34: At that time we captured all his cities and claimed them for God by destroying men, women, and children. There were no survivors.
2.35: However, we did loot the cities that we captured, taking the cattle and goods.
2.36: From Aroer on the edge of the Arnon Valley and the city in that valley as far as Gilead, no city had walls that could keep us out. The LORD our God gave us all of them.
2.37: But the LORD our God had forbidden you to go anywhere near the land of the Ammonites. So you didn't enter the land along the bank of the Jabbok River or capture the cities in the mountains.

3.1: Next we turned and followed the road that goes to Bashan. King Og of Bashan and all his troops came to fight us at Edrei.
3.2: The LORD said to me, "Don't be afraid of him. I'll hand him, all his troops, and his land over to you. Do to him what you did to King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon."
3.3: So the LORD our God also handed King Og of Bashan and all his troops over to us. We defeated him, leaving no survivors.
3.4: At that time we captured all of his cities. There wasn't a city we didn't take. We captured a total of 60 cities-the whole territory of Argob, the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
3.5: All of these cities were fortified with high walls and double-door gates with bars across the gates. We also captured a large number of unwalled villages.
3.6: We claimed them all for God, destroying every city, including men, women, and children-as we did to King Sihon of Heshbon.
3.7: However, we did loot the cities, taking all of the cattle and goods.
3.8: We took the land of the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan River, from the Arnon Valley to Mount Hermon.
3.9: (The Sidonians call Mount Hermon by the name Sirion, and the Amorites call it Senir.)
3.10: We took all of the cities of the plateau, all of Gilead, and all of Bashan as far as Salcah and Edrei, cities of Og's kingdom in Bashan.
3.11: (Of the Rephaim only King Og of Bashan was left. His bed was made of iron and was more than 13 feet long and 6 feet wide. It is still in the Ammonite city of Rabbah.)
3.12: At that time we took possession of this land. I gave the tribes of Reuben and Gad the land north of Aroer near the Arnon Valley and half of the mountain region of Gilead with its cities.
3.13: I gave the rest of Gilead and all of Bashan ruled by Og to half of the tribe of Manasseh. (The whole territory of Argob in Bashan used to be called the land of the Rephaim.
3.14: Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, took the whole territory of Argob as far as the border of the Geshurites and the Maacathites. The settlements in Bashan he named Havvoth Jair after himself. This is still their name today.)
3.16: I gave the tribes of Reuben and Gad some of Gilead from the Arnon Valley (the middle of the valley is the border) to the Jabbok River, which is the border of Ammon.
3.17: Their land included the plains around the Jordan River. The western border was the river, from the Sea of Galilee to the Sea of the Plains (the Dead Sea), which is near Mount Pisgah on the east.
3.18: I gave the tribes of Reuben and Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh this command: "The LORD your God has given you this land so that you can take possession of it. All your soldiers must be ready for battle when they cross [the Jordan River] ahead of the other Israelites.
3.19: I know you have a lot of livestock. Your wives, children, and livestock must stay here in the cities that I gave you.
3.20: Your soldiers will go with the other Israelites until they take possession of the land the LORD your God is giving them on the other side of the Jordan River. Then they will have a place to rest as you have. After that each of you may go back to the land I gave you."
3.21: I also gave Joshua this command: "You have seen with your own eyes everything that the LORD your God has done to these two kings. The LORD will do the same to all of the kingdoms on the other side [of the Jordan River] where you're going.
3.22: Don't be afraid of them, because the LORD your God himself will fight for you."
3.23: Then I pleaded with the LORD:
3.24: "Almighty LORD, you have [only] begun to show me how great and powerful you are. What kind of god is there in heaven or on earth who can do the deeds and the mighty acts you have done?
3.25: Please let me go over and see the beautiful land on the other side of the Jordan River-those beautiful mountains in Lebanon."
3.26: The LORD was angry with me because of you, so he wouldn't listen to me. He said, "That's enough out of you! Don't talk to me anymore about this.
3.27: Go to the top of Mount Pisgah, and look west, north, south, and east. You may look at the land, but you will never cross the Jordan River.
3.28: Give instructions to Joshua. Encourage and strengthen him, because he will lead these people across [the Jordan River], and he will help them take possession of the land you see."
3.29: So we stayed in the valley near Beth Peor.

4.1: Israel, listen to the laws and rules I am about to teach you. Obey them so that you will live and be able to enter and take possession of the land that the LORD God of your ancestors is giving you.
4.2: Never add anything to what I command you, or take anything away from it. Then you will be able to obey the commands of the LORD your God that I give you.
4.3: With your own eyes you saw what the LORD did at Baal Peor. The LORD your God destroyed everyone among you who worshiped the god Baal while you were at Peor.
4.4: But you were loyal to the LORD your God and are still alive today.
4.5: I have taught you laws and rules as the LORD my God commanded me. You must obey them when you've entered the land and taken possession of it.
4.6: Faithfully obey these laws. This will show the people of the world your wisdom and insight. When they hear about all these laws, they will say, "What wise and insightful people there are in this great nation!"
4.7: What great nation ever had their gods as near to them as the LORD our God is near to us whenever we pray to him?
4.8: Or what other great nation has such fair laws and rules as all these teachings I am giving you today?
4.9: However, be careful, and watch yourselves closely so that you don't forget the things which you have seen with your own eyes. Don't let them fade from your memory as long as you live. Teach them to your children and grandchildren.
4.10: Never forget the day you stood in front of the LORD your God at Mount Horeb. The LORD had said to me, "Assemble the people in front of me, and I will let them hear my words. Then they will learn to fear me as long as they live on earth, and they will teach their children the same thing."
4.11: So you came and stood at the foot of the mountain, which was on fire with flames shooting into the sky. It was dark, cloudy, and gloomy.
4.12: The LORD spoke to you from the fire. You heard a voice speaking but saw no one. There was only a voice.
4.13: The LORD told you about the terms of his promise, the ten commandments, which he commanded you to do. Then he wrote them on two stone tablets.
4.14: The LORD also commanded me to teach you the laws and rules you must obey after you cross [the Jordan River] and take possession of the land.
4.15: You didn't see the LORD the day he spoke to you from the fire at Mount Horeb. So be very careful
4.16: that you don't become corrupt and make your own carved idols. Don't make statues that represent men or women,
4.17: any animal on earth, any creature with wings that flies,
4.18: any creature that crawls on the ground, or any fish in the water.
4.19: Don't let yourselves be tempted to worship and serve what you see in the sky-the sun, the moon, the stars, or anything else. The LORD your God has given them to all people everywhere.
4.20: But you are the people the LORD brought out of Egypt, the iron smelter, in order to make you his own people as you still are today.
4.21: The LORD was angry with me because of you. So the LORD your God took an oath that I wouldn't cross the Jordan River and enter the good land he is giving you as your property.
4.22: I'm going to die in this land and not cross the Jordan River, but you're going to go across and take possession of that good land.
4.23: Be careful that you don't forget the promise that the LORD your God made to you. Don't make your own carved idols or statues that represent anything the LORD your God has forbidden.
4.24: The LORD your God is a raging fire, a God who does not tolerate rivals.
4.25: Even when you have children and grandchildren and have grown old in that land, don't become corrupt and make carved idols or statues that represent anything. I call heaven and earth as witnesses against you today: If you do this thing that the LORD your God considers evil, making him furious,
4.26: you will quickly disappear from the land you're going to possess on the other side of the Jordan River. You won't live very long there. You'll be completely wiped out.
4.27: The LORD will scatter you among the people of the world, and only a few of you will be left among the nations where the LORD will force you to live.
4.28: There you will worship wooden and stone gods made by human hands. These gods can't see, hear, eat, or smell.
4.29: But if you look for the LORD your God when you are among those nations, you will find him whenever you search for him with all your heart and with all your soul.
4.30: When you're in distress and all these things happen to you, then you will finally come back to the LORD your God and obey him.
4.31: The LORD your God is a merciful God. He will not abandon you, destroy you, or forget the promise to your ancestors that he swore he would keep.
4.32: Search the distant past, long before your time. Start from the very day God created people on earth. Search from one end of heaven to the other. Has anything as great as this ever happened before, or has anything like it ever been heard of?
4.33: Have any [other] people ever heard God speak from a fire and lived? You did!
4.34: Or has any god ever tried to come and take one nation away from another for himself? The LORD your God used his mighty hand and powerful arm to do this for you in Egypt. He did this using plagues, miraculous signs, amazing things, and war. He did his great and awe-inspiring deeds in front of you.
4.35: You were shown these things so that you would know that the LORD is God. There is no other god.
4.36: He let you hear his voice from heaven so that he could instruct you. He showed you his great fire on earth, and you heard him speak from the column of fire.
4.37: Because he loved your ancestors and chose their descendants, he was with you as he brought you out of Egypt by his great power.
4.38: He forced nations greater and stronger than you out of your way to bring you into their land and give it to you. This land is your own possession today.
4.39: Remember today, and never forget that the LORD is God in heaven above and here on earth. There is no other god.
4.40: Obey his laws and commands which I'm giving you today. Then things will go well for you and your descendants. You will live for a long time in the land. The LORD your God is giving you the land for as long as you live.
4.41: Then Moses set aside three cities on the east side of the Jordan River.
4.42: Those who unintentionally killed someone whom they had never hated could flee to one of these cities and save their lives.
4.43: The cities were Bezer on the desert plateau for the tribe of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead for the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashan for the tribe of Manasseh.
4.44: This is what Moses taught the people of Israel.
4.45: These are the commandments, laws, and rules Moses gave the Israelites after they had left Egypt.
4.46: He gave these to the people when they were east of the Jordan River in the valley near Beth Peor, in the land of King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon. Moses and Israel defeated him after they left Egypt.
4.47: They took possession of his land and the land of King Og of Bashan, the two kings of the Amorites who were east of the Jordan River.
4.48: This land went from Aroer on the edge of the Arnon Valley to Mount Siyon (that is, Mount Hermon).
4.49: It included all the plains on the east side of the Jordan River as far as the Dead Sea at the foot of the slopes of Mount Pisgah.

5.1: Moses summoned all Israel and said to them: Israel, listen to the laws and rules I'm telling you today. Learn them and faithfully obey them.
5.2: The LORD our God made a promise to us at Mount Horeb.
5.3: He didn't make this promise to our ancestors, but to all of us who are alive here today.
5.4: The LORD spoke to you face to face from the fire on the mountain.
5.5: I stood between the LORD and you to tell you the word of the LORD, because you were afraid of the fire and didn't go up on the mountain. The LORD said:
5.6: "I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of slavery in Egypt.
5.8: Never make your own carved idols or statues that represent any creature in the sky, on the earth, or in the water.
5.9: Never worship them or serve them, because I, the LORD your God, am a God who does not tolerate rivals. I punish children for their parents' sins to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me.
5.10: But I show mercy to thousands of generations of those who love me and obey my commandments.
5.11: "Never use the name of the LORD your God carelessly. The LORD will make sure that anyone who uses his name carelessly will be punished.
5.12: "Observe the day of worship as a holy day. This is what the LORD your God has commanded you.
5.13: You have six days to do all your work.
5.14: The seventh day is the day of worship dedicated to the LORD your God. You, your sons, your daughters, your male and female slaves, your oxen, your donkeys-all of your animals-even the foreigners living in your city must never do any work [on that day]. In this way your male and female slaves can rest as you do.
5.15: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and that the LORD your God used his mighty hand and powerful arm to bring you out of there. This is why the LORD your God has commanded you to observe the day of worship.
5.16: "Honor your father and your mother as the LORD your God has commanded you. Then you will live for a long time, and things will go well for you in the land the LORD your God is giving you.
5.20: "Never avoid the truth when you testify about your neighbor.
5.21: "Never desire to take your neighbor's wife away from him. "Never long for your neighbor's household, his field, his male or female slave, his ox, his donkey, or anything else that belongs to him."
5.22: These are the commandments the LORD spoke to your whole assembly on the mountain. He spoke in a loud voice from the fire, the cloud, and the gloomy darkness. Then he stopped speaking. He wrote the commandments on two stone tablets and gave them to me.
5.23: But when you heard the voice coming from the darkness and saw the mountain blazing with fire, all the leaders and heads of your tribes came to me.
5.24: You said, "The LORD our God has let us see how great and glorious he is. We've heard his voice come from the fire. Today we've seen that people can live even if God speaks to them.
5.25: Why should we die? This great fire will consume us! If we continue to hear the voice of the LORD our God, we'll die!
5.26: Who has ever heard the voice of the living God speak from a fire, as we did, and lived?
5.27: [Moses,] go and listen to everything that the LORD our God says. Then tell us whatever the LORD our God tells you. We'll listen and obey."
